0	My grandfather was seriously ill, he had only a few days left to live. I had always loved him, but never told him. I was very sad when I saw that.

9	This is a Tale about a tail--a tail that belonged to a little red squirrel, and his name was Nutkin.
9	He had a brother called Twinkleberry, and a great many cousins: they lived in a wood at the edge of a lake.
9	In the middle of the lake there is an island covered with trees and nut bushes; and amongst those trees stands a hollow oak-tree, which is the house of an owl who is called Old Brown.
9	One autumn when the nuts were ripe, and the leaves on the hazel bushes were golden and green-- Nutkin and Twinkleberry and all the other little squirrels came out of the wood, and down to the edge of the lake.
9	They made little rafts out of twigs, and they paddled away over the water to Owl Island to gather nuts.
9	Each squirrel had a little sack and a large oar, and spread out his tail for a sail.
9	They also took with them an offering of three fat mice as a present for Old Brown, and put them down upon his door-step.
9	Then Twinkleberry and the other little squirrels each made a low bow, and said politely--
9	"Old Mr. Brown, will you favour us with permission to gather nuts upon your island?"
9	But Nutkin was excessively impertinent in his manners.
9	He bobbed up and down like a little red CHERRY, singing--
9	"Riddle me, riddle me, rot-tot-tote!
9	A little wee man, in a red red coat!
9	A staff in his hand, and a stone in his throat; If you'll tell me this riddle, I'll give you a groat."
2	Now this riddle is as old as the hills; Mr. Brown paid no attention whatever to Nutkin.
2	He shut his eyes obstinately and went to sleep.
9	The squirrels filled their little sacks with nuts, and sailed away home in the evening.
9	But next morning they all came back again to Owl Island; and Twinkleberry and the others brought a fine fat mole, and laid it on the stone in front of Old Brown's doorway, and said--
9	"Mr. Brown, will you favour us with your gracious permission to gather some more nuts?"
9	But Nutkin, who had no respect, began to dance up and down, tickling old Mr. Brown with a NETTLE and singing--
8	"Old Mr. B!
8	Riddle-me-ree!
8	Hitty Pitty within the wall, Hitty Pitty without the wall; If you touch Hitty Pitty, Hitty Pitty will bite you!"
1	Mr. Brown woke up suddenly and carried the mole into his house.
9	Presently a little thread of blue SMOKE from a wood fire came up from the top of the tree, and Nutkin peeped through the key-hole and sang--
9	"A house full, a hole full!
9	And you cannot gather a bowl-full!"
9	The squirrels searched for nuts all over the island and filled their little sacks.
9	But Nutkin gathered oak-apples-- yellow and scarlet--and sat upon a beech-stump playing marbles, and watching the door of old Mr. Brown.
9	On the third day the squirrels got up very early and went fishing; they caught seven fat minnows as a present for Old Brown.
9	They paddled over the lake and landed under a crooked chestnut tree on Owl Island.
9	Twinkleberry and six other little squirrels each carried a fat minnow; but Nutkin, who had no nice manners, brought no present at all.
9	He ran in front, singing--
8	"The man in the wilderness said to me, `How may strawberries grow in the sea?'
8	I answered him as I thought good-- `As many red herrings as grow in the wood."'
9	But old Mr. Brown took no interest in riddles--not even when the answer was provided for him.
9	On the fourth day the squirrels brought a present of six fat beetles, which were as good as plums in PLUM-PUDDING for Old Brown.
9	Each beetle was wrapped up carefully in a dockleaf, fastened with a pine-needle- pin.
9	But Nutkin sang as rudely as ever--
8	"Old Mr. B! riddle-me-ree!
8	Flour of England, fruit of Spain, Met together in a shower of rain; Put in a bag tied round with a string, If you'll tell me this riddle, I'll give you a ring!"
9	Which was ridiculous of Nutkin, because he had not got any ring to give to Old Brown.
9	The other squirrels hunted up and down the nut bushes; but Nutkin gathered robin's pin-cushions off a briar bush, and stuck them full of pine-needle-pins.
9	On the fifth day the squirrels brought a present of wild honey; it was so sweet and sticky that they licked their fingers as they put it down upon the stone.
9	They had stolen it out of a bumble BEES' nest on the tippity top of the hill.
9	But Nutkin skipped up and down, singing--
8	"Hum-a-bum! buzz! buzz!
8	Hum-a-bum buzz!
8	As I went over Tipple-tine I met a flock of bonny swine; Some yellow-nacked, some yellow backed!
8	They were the very bonniest swine That e'er went over the Tipple-tine."
2	Old Mr. Brown turned up his eyes in disgust at the impertinence of Nutkin.
9	But he ate up the honey!
9	The squirrels filled their little sacks with nuts.
9	But Nutkin sat upon a big flat rock, and played ninepins with a crab apple and green fir-cones.
9	On the sixth day, which was Saturday, the squirrels came again for the last time; they brought a new-laid EGG in a little rush basket as a last parting present for Old Brown.
8	But Nutkin ran in front laughing, and shouting--
8	"Humpty Dumpty lies in the beck, With a white counterpane round his neck, Forty doctors and forty wrights, Cannot put Humpty Dumpty to rights!"
9	Now old Mr. Brown took an interest in eggs; he opened one eye and shut it again.
9	But still he did not speak.
9	Nutkin became more and more impertinent--
8	"Old Mr. B!
8	Old Mr. B!
8	Hickamore, Hackamore, on the King's kitchen door; All the King's horses, and all the King's men, Couldn't drive Hickamore, Hackamore, Off the King's kitchen door!"
8	Nutkin danced up and down like a SUNBEAM; but still Old Brown said nothing at all.
9	Nutkin began again--
8	"Authur O'Bower has broken his band, He comes roaring up the land!
8	The King of Scots with all his power, Cannot turn Arthur of the Bower!"
9	Nutkin made a whirring noise to sound like the WIND, and he took a running jump right onto the head of Old Brown!
9	. . .
1	Then all at once there was a flutterment and a scufflement and a loud "Squeak!"
7	The other squirrels scuttered away into the bushes.
7	When they came back very cautiously, peeping round the tree-- there was Old Brown sitting on his door-step, quite still, with his eyes closed, as if nothing had happened.
9	* * * * * * * *
1	BUT NUTKIN WAS IN HIS WAISTCOAT POCKET!
9	This looks like the end of the story; but it isn't.
5	And to this day, if you meet Nutkin up a tree and ask him a riddle, he will throw sticks at you, and stamp his feet and scold, and shout--
5	"Cuck-cuck-cuck-cur-r-r-cuck-k!"
9	Once upon a time there were three little kittens, and their names were Mittens, Tom Kitten, and Moppet.
9	They had dear little fur coats of their own; and they tumbled about the doorstep and played in the dust.
9	But one day their mother--Mrs.
9	Tabitha Twitchit--expected friends to tea; so she fetched the kittens indoors, to wash and dress them, before the fine company arrived.
9	First she scrubbed their faces (this one is Moppet).
9	Then she brushed their fur (this one is Mittens).
9	Then she combed their tails and whiskers (this is Tom Kitten).
5	Tom was very naughty, and he scratched.
9	Mrs. Tabitha dressed Moppet and Mittens in clean pinafores and tuckers; and then she took all sorts of elegant uncomfortable clothes out of a chest of drawers, in order to dress up her son Thomas.
9	Tom Kitten was very fat, and he had grown; several buttons burst off.
9	His mother sewed them on again.
9	When the three kittens were ready, Mrs. Tabitha unwisely turned them out into the garden, to be out of the way while she made hot buttered toast.
5	"Now keep your frocks clean, children!
9	You must walk on your hind legs.
9	Keep away from the dirty ash- pit, and from Sally Henny Penny, and from the pigsty and the Puddle- ducks."
9	Moppet and Mittens walked down the garden path unsteadily.
9	Presently they trod upon their pinafores and fell on their noses.
9	When they stood up there were several green smears!
9	"Let us climb up the rockery and sit on the garden wall," said Moppet.
9	They turned their pinafores back to front and went up with a skip and a jump; Moppet's white tucker fell down into the road.
9	Tom Kitten was quite unable to jump when walking upon his hind legs in trousers.
9	He came up the rockery by degrees, breaking the ferns and shedding buttons right and left.
9	He was all in pieces when he reached the top of the wall.
9	Moppet and Mittens tried to pull him together; his hat fell off, and the rest of his buttons burst.
9	While they were in difficulties, there was a pit pat, paddle pat! and the three Puddle-ducks came along the hard high road, marching one behind the other and doing the goose step-- pit pat, paddle pat! pit pat, waddle pat!
9	They stopped and stood in a row and stared up at the kittens.
9	Then the two duck-birds, Rebeccah and Jemima Puddle-duck, picked up the hat and tucker and put them on.
8	Mittens laughed so that she fell off the wall.
9	Moppet and Tom descended after her; the pinafores and all the rest of Tom's clothes came off on the way down.
9	"Come!
9	Mr. Drake Puddle-duck," said Moppet.
9	"Come and help us to dress him!
9	Come and button up Tom!"
9	Mr. Drake Puddle-duck advanced in a slow sideways manner and picked up the various articles.
1	But he put them on HIMSELF!
9	They fitted him even worse than Tom Kitten.
8	"It's a very fine morning!" said Mr. Drake Puddle-duck.
9	And he and Jemima and Rebeccah Puddle-duck set off up the road, keeping step--pit pat, paddle pat! pit pat, waddle pat!
9	Then Tabitha Twitchit came down the garden and found her kittens on the wall with no clothes on.
5	She pulled them off the wall, smacked them, and took them back to the house.
5	"My friends will arrive in a minute, and you are not fit to be seen; I am affronted," said Mrs. Tabitha Twitchit.
9	She sent them upstairs; and I am sorry to say she told her friends that they were in bed with the measles-- which was not true.
9	Quite the contrary; they were not in bed: NOT in the least.
2	Somehow there were very extra-- ordinary noises overhead, which disturbed the dignity and repose of the tea party.
9	And I think that some day I shall have to make another, larger book, to tell you more about Tom Kitten!
9	As for the Puddle-ducks--they went into a pond.
9	The clothes all came off directly, because there were no buttons.
9	And Mr. Drake Puddle-duck, and Jemima and Rebeccah, have been looking for them ever since.
9	Once upon a time there was a woodmouse, and her name was Mrs. Tittlemouse.
9	She lived in a bank under a hedge.
9	Such a funny house!
9	There were yards and yards of sandy passages, leading to store- rooms and nut cellars and seed cellars, all amongst the roots of the hedge.
9	There was a kitchen, a parlor, a pantry, and a larder.
9	Also, there was Mrs. Tittle- mouse's bedroom, where she slept in a little box bed!
9	Mrs. Tittlemouse was a most terribly tidy particular little mouse, always sweeping and dusting the soft sandy floors.
9	Sometimes a beetle lost its way in the passages.
2	"Shuh! shuh! little dirty feet!" said Mrs. Tittlemouse, clattering her dustpan.
9	And one day a little old woman ran up and down in a red spotty cloak.
1	"Your house is on fire, Mother Ladybird!
1	Fly away home to your children!"
9	Another day, a big fat spider came in to shelter from the rain.
9	"Beg pardon, is this not Miss Muffet's?"
2	Leaving ends of cobweb all over my nice clean house!"
9	She bundled the spider out at a window.
9	He let himself down the hedge with a long thin bit of string.
9	Mrs. Tittlemouse went on her way to a distant storeroom, to fetch cherrystones and thistle- down seed for dinner.
9	All along the passage she sniffed, and looked at the floor.
9	"I smell a smell of honey; is it the cowslips outside, in the hedge?
2	I am sure I can see the marks of little dirty feet."
8	Suddenly round a corner, she met Babbitty Bumble--"Zizz, Bizz, Bizzz!" said the bumble bee.
0	She wished that she had a broom.
9	"Good-day, Babbitty Bumble; I should be glad to buy some bees- wax.
9	But what are you doing down here?
2	Why do you always come in at a window, and say, Zizz, Bizz, Bizzz?"
5	Mrs. Tittle- mouse began to get cross.
5	"Zizz, Wizz, Wizzz!" replied Babbitty Bumble in a peevish squeak.
9	She sidled down a passage, and disappeared into a storeroom which had been used for acorns.
9	Mrs. Tittlemouse had eaten the acorns before Christmas; the storeroom ought to have been empty.
9	But it was full of untidy dry moss.
9	Mrs. Tittlemouse began to pull out the moss.
9	Three or four other bees put their heads out, and buzzed fiercely.
5	"I am not in the habit of letting lodgings; this is an intrusion!" said Mrs. Tittlemouse.
5	"I will have them turned out --" "Buzz!
9	Buzz!
9	Buzzz!"--"I wonder who would help me?"
9	"Bizz, Wizz, Wizzz!"
9	--"I will not have Mr. Jackson; he never wipes his feet."
9	Mrs. Tittlemouse decided to leave the bees till after dinner.
9	When she got back to the parlor, she heard some one coughing in a fat voice; and there sat Mr. Jackson himself.
8	He was sitting all over a small rocking chair, twiddling his thumbs and smiling, with his feet on the fender.
9	He lived in a drain below the hedge, in a very dirty wet ditch.
9	"How do you do, Mr. Jackson?
1	Deary me, you have got very wet!"
8	"Thank you, thank you, thank you, Mrs. Tittlemouse!
9	I'll sit awhile and dry myself," said Mr. Jackson.
8	He sat and smiled, and the water dripped off his coat tails.
9	Mrs. Tittlemouse went round with a mop.
9	He sat such a while that he had to be asked if he would take some dinner?
9	First she offered him cherry- stones.
8	"Thank you, thank you, Mrs. Tittlemouse!
9	No teeth, no teeth, no teeth!" said Mr. Jackson.
9	He opened his mouth most unnecessarily wide; he certainly had not a tooth in his head.
9	Then she offered him thistle- down seed--"Tiddly, widdly, widdly!
9	Pouff, pouff, puff." said Mr. Jackson.
9	He blew the thistle- down all over the room.
8	"Thank you, thank you, thank you, Mrs. Tittlemouse!
8	Now what I really--REALLY should like-- would be a little dish of honey!"
0	"I am afraid I have not got any, Mr. Jackson!" said Mrs. Tittlemouse.
8	"Tiddly, widdly, widdly, Mrs. Tittlemouse!" said the smiling Mr. Jackson, "I can SMELL it; that is why I came to call."
9	Mr. Jackson rose ponderously from the table, and began to look into the cupboards.
9	Mrs. Tittlemouse followed him with a dishcloth, to wipe his large wet footmarks off the parlor floor.
9	When he had convinced himself that there was no honey in the cupboards, he began to walk down the passage.
9	"Indeed, indeed, you will stick fast, Mr. Jackson!"
9	"Tiddly, widdly, widdly, Mrs. Tittlemouse!"
9	First he squeezed into the pantry.
1	"Tiddly, widdly, widdly?
1	No honey?
1	No honey, Mrs. Tittlemouse?"
9	There were three creepy-crawly people hiding in the plate rack.
9	Two of them got away; but the littlest one he caught.
9	Then he squeezed into the larder.
9	Miss Butterfly was tasting the sugar; but she flew away out of the window.
1	"Tiddly, widdly, widdly, Mrs. Tittlemouse; you seem to have plenty of visitors!"
2	"And without any invitation!" said Mrs. Thomasina Tittlemouse.
9	They went along the sandy passage--"Tiddly, widdly--" "Buzz!
9	Wizz!
9	Wizz!"
9	He met Babbitty round a corner, and snapped her up, and put her down again.
2	"I do not like bumble bees.
2	They are all over bristles," said Mr. Jackson, wiping his mouth with his coat sleeve.
5	"Get out, you nasty old toad!" shrieked Babbitty Bumble.
5	"I shall go distracted!" scolded Mrs. Tittlemouse.
9	She shut herself up in the nut cellar while Mr. Jackson pulled out the bees-nest.
9	He seemed to have no objection to stings.
9	When Mrs. Tittlemouse ventured to come out--everybody had gone away.
9	She gathered up the moss and the remains of the bees- wax.
9	Then she went out and fetched some twigs, to partly close up the front door.
5	"I will make it too small for Mr. Jackson!"
9	She fetched soft soap, and flannel, and a new scrubbing brush from the storeroom.
9	But she was too tired to do any more.
9	First she fell asleep in her chair, and then she went to bed.
9	Next morning she got up very early and began a spring cleaning which lasted a fort- night.
9	She swept, and scrubbed, and dusted; and she rubbed up the furniture with bees- wax, and polished her little tin spoons.
9	When it was all beautifully neat and clean, she gave a party to five other little mice, without Mr. Jackson.
9	He smelt the party and came up the bank, but he could not squeeze in at the door.
9	So they handed him out acorn cupfuls of honeydew through the window, and he was not at all offended.
8	He sat outside in the sun, and said--"Tiddly, widdly, widdly!
8	Your very good health, Mrs. Tittlemouse!"
9	Once upon a time there was an old cat, called Mrs. Tabitha Twitchit, who was an anxious parent.
9	She used to lose her kittens continually, and whenever they were lost they were always in mischief!
9	On baking day she determined to shut them up in a cupboard.
9	She caught Moppet and Mittens, but she could not find Tom.
9	Mrs. Tabitha went up and down all over the house, mewing for Tom Kitten.
9	She looked in the pantry under the staircase, and she searched the best spare bedroom that was all covered up with dust sheets.
9	She went right upstairs and looked into the attics, but she could not find him anywhere.
9	It was an old, old house, full of cupboards and passages.
9	Some of the walls were four feet thick, and there used to be queer noises inside them, as if there might be a little secret staircase.
9	Certainly there were odd little jagged doorways in the wainscot, and things disappeared at night-- especially cheese and bacon.
7	Mrs. Tabitha became more and more distracted and mewed dreadfully.
9	While their mother was searching the house, Moppet and Mittens had got into mischief.
9	The cupboard door was not locked, so they pushed it open and came out.
9	They went straight to the dough which was set to rise in a pan before the fire.
8	They patted it with their little soft paws--"Shall we make dear little muffins?" said Mittens to Moppet.
7	But just at that moment somebody knocked at the front door, and Moppet jumped into the flour barrel in a fright.
7	Mittens ran away to the dairy and hid in an empty jar on the stone shelf where the milk pans stand.
9	The visitor was a neighbor, Mrs. Ribby; she had called to borrow some yeast.
0	I'm in sad trouble, Cousin Ribby," said Tabitha, shedding tears.
9	Where have you looked for him?"
0	"All over the house!
0	The rats are too many for me.
5	What a thing it is to have an unruly family!" said Mrs. Tabitha Twitchit.
5	"I'm not afraid of rats; I will help you to find him; and whip him, too!
9	What is all that soot in the fender?"
1	"The chimney wants sweeping-- Oh, dear me, Cousin Ribby--now Moppet and Mittens are gone!
1	"They have both got out of the cupboard!"
9	Ribby and Tabitha set to work to search the house thoroughly again.
9	They poked under the beds with Ribby's umbrella and they rummaged in cupboards.
9	They even fetched a candle and looked inside a clothes chest in one of the attics.
9	They could not find anything, but once they heard a door bang and somebody scuttered downstairs.
0	"Yes, it is infested with rats," said Tabitha tearfully.
9	"I caught seven young ones out of one hole in the back kitchen, and we had them for dinner last Saturday.
9	And once I saw the old father rat--an enormous old rat-- Cousin Ribby.
9	I was just going to jump upon him, when he showed his yellow teeth at me and whisked down the hole.
9	Ribby and Tabitha searched and searched.
9	They both heard a curious roly-poly noise under the attic floor.
9	But there was nothing to be seen.
9	They returned to the kitchen.
1	"Here's one of your kittens at least," said Ribby, dragging Moppet out of the flour barrel.
9	They shook the flour off her and set her down on the kitchen floor.
7	She seemed to be in a terrible fright.
9	The two cats ran to look at the dough pan.
9	Sure enough there were marks of little scratching fingers, and a lump of dough was gone!
9	"Which way did she go, Moppet?"
7	But Moppet had been too much frightened to peep out of the barrel again.
9	Ribby and Tabitha took her with them to keep her safely in sight, while they went on with their search.
9	They went into the dairy.
9	The first thing they found was Mittens, hiding in an empty jar.
9	They tipped over the jar, and she scrambled out.
7	"Oh, Mother, Mother!" said Mittens--
7	"Oh!
9	Ribby and Tabitha looked at one another.
1	"A rolling pin and butter!
7	Oh, my poor son Thomas!" exclaimed Tabitha, wringing her paws.
9	"A rolling pin?" said Ribby.
9	"Did we not hear a roly-poly noise in the attic when we were looking into that chest?"
9	Ribby and Tabitha rushed upstairs again.
9	Sure enough the roly-poly noise was still going on quite distinctly under the attic floor.
7	"This is serious, Cousin Tabitha," said Ribby.
7	"We must send for John Joiner at once, with a saw."
9	Now, this is what had been happening to Tom Kitten, and it shows how very unwise it is to go up a chimney in a very old house, where a person does not know his way, and where there are enormous rats.
9	Tom Kitten did not want to be shut up in a cupboard.
9	When he saw that his mother was going to bake, he determined to hide.
9	He looked about for a nice convenient place, and he fixed upon the chimney.
9	The fire had only just been lighted, and it was not hot; but there was a white choky smoke from the green sticks.
9	Tom Kitten got upon the fender and looked up.
9	It was a big old- fashioned fireplace.
9	The chimney itself was wide enough inside for a man to stand up and walk about.
9	So there was plenty of room for a little Tom Cat.
9	He jumped right up into the fireplace, balancing himself upon the iron bar where the kettle hangs.
9	Tom Kitten took another big jump off the bar and landed on a ledge high up inside the chimney, knocking down some soot into the fender.
9	Tom Kitten coughed and choked with the smoke; he could hear the sticks beginning to crackle and burn in the fireplace down below.
9	He made up his mind to climb right to the top, and get out on the slates, and try to catch sparrows.
7	"I cannot go back.
7	If I slipped I might fall in the fire and singe my beautiful tail and my little blue jacket."
9	The chimney was a very big old- fashioned one.
9	It was built in the days when people burnt logs of wood upon the hearth.
9	The chimney stack stood up above the roof like a little stone tower, and the daylight shone down from the top, under the slanting slates that kept out the rain.
7	Tom Kitten was getting very frightened!
9	He climbed up, and up, and up.
9	Then he waded sideways through inches of soot.
9	He was like a little sweep himself.
7	It was most confusing in the dark.
9	One flue seemed to lead into another.
7	There was less smoke, but Tom Kitten felt quite lost.
9	He scrambled up and up; but before he reached the chimney top he came to a place where somebody had loosened a stone in the wall.
9	There were some mutton bones lying about.
9	"This seems funny," said Tom Kitten.
9	"Who has been gnawing bones up here in the chimney?
7	I wish I had never come!
7	And what a funny smell?
7	It is something like mouse, only dreadfully strong.
9	It makes me sneeze," said Tom Kitten.
9	He squeezed through the hole in the wall and dragged himself along a most uncomfortably tight passage where there was scarcely any light.
9	He groped his way carefully for several yards; he was at the back of the skirting board in the attic, where there is a little mark * in the picture.
9	All at once he fell head over heels in the dark, down a hole, and landed on a heap of very dirty rags.
1	When Tom Kitten picked himself up and looked about him, he found himself in a place that he had never seen before, although he had lived all his life in the house.
9	It was a very small stuffy fusty room, with boards, and rafters, and cobwebs, and lath and plaster.
9	Opposite to him--as far away as he could sit--was an enormous rat.
5	"What do you mean by tumbling into my bed all covered with smuts?" said the rat, chattering his teeth.
7	"Please, sir, the chimney wants sweeping," said poor Tom Kitten.
5	"Anna Maria!
5	Anna Maria!" squeaked the rat.
9	There was a pattering noise and an old woman rat poked her head round a rafter.
1	All in a minute she rushed upon Tom Kitten, and before he knew what was happening.
9	. .
9	. . . his coat was pulled off, and he was rolled up in a bundle, and tied with string in very hard knots.
9	Anna Maria did the tying.
9	The old rat watched her and took snuff.
9	When she had finished, they both sat staring at him with their mouths open.
8	"Anna Maria," said the old man rat (whose name was Samuel Whiskers), "Anna Maria, make me a kitten dumpling roly-poly pudding for my dinner."
9	"It requires dough and a pat of butter and a rolling pin," said Anna Maria, considering Tom Kitten with her head on one side.
5	"No," said Samuel Whiskers, "make it properly, Anna Maria, with breadcrumbs."
5	Butter and dough," replied Anna Maria.
9	The two rats consulted together for a few minutes and then went away.
9	Samuel Whiskers got through a hole in the wainscot and went boldly down the front staircase to the dairy to get the butter.
9	He did not meet anybody.
9	He made a second journey for the rolling pin.
9	He pushed it in front of him with his paws, like a brewer's man trundling a barrel.
9	He could hear Ribby and Tabitha talking, but they were too busy lighting the candle to look into the chest.
9	They did not see him.
9	Anna Maria went down by way of skirting board and a window shutter to the kitchen to steal the dough.
9	She borrowed a small saucer and scooped up the dough with her paws.
9	She did not observe Moppet.
7	While Tom Kitten was left alone under the floor of the attic, he wriggled about and tried to mew for help.
9	But his mouth was full of soot and cobwebs, and he was tied up in such very tight knots, he could not make anybody hear him.
9	Except a spider who came out of a crack in the ceiling and examined the knots critically, from a safe distance.
9	It was a judge of knots because it had a habit of tying up unfortunate bluebottles.
9	It did not offer to assist him.
7	Tom Kitten wriggled and squirmed until he was quite exhausted.
9	Presently the rats came back and set to work to make him into a dumpling.
9	First they smeared him with butter, and then they rolled him in the dough.
9	"Will not the string be very indigestible, Anna Maria?" inquired Samuel Whiskers.
5	Anna Maria said she thought that it was of no consequence; but she wished that Tom Kitten would hold his head still, as it disarranged the pastry.
9	She laid hold of his ears.
5	Tom Kitten bit and spit, and mewed and wriggled; and the rolling pin went roly-poly, roly; roly-poly, roly.
9	The rats each held an end.
2	"His tail is sticking out!
2	You did not fetch enough dough, Anna Maria."
5	"I fetched as much as I could carry," replied Anna Maria.
5	"I do not think"--said Samuel Whiskers, pausing to take a look at Tom Kitten--"I do NOT think it will be a good pudding.
2	It smells sooty."
1	Anna Maria was about to argue the point when all at once there began to be other sounds up above--the rasping noise of a saw, and the noise of a little dog, scratching and yelping!
7	"We are discovered and interrupted, Anna Maria; let us collect our property--and other people's--and depart at once.
0	"I fear that we shall be obliged to leave this pudding.
2	"But I am persuaded that the knots would have proved indigestible, whatever you may urge to the contrary."
9	"Come away at once and help me to tie up some mutton bones in a counterpane," said Anna Maria.
9	"I have got half a smoked ham hidden in the chimney."
9	So it happened that by the time John Joiner had got the plank up-- there was nobody here under the floor except the rolling pin and Tom Kitten in a very dirty dumpling!
5	But there was a strong smell of rats; and John Joiner spent the rest of the morning sniffing and whining, and wagging his tail, and going round and round with his head in the hole like a gimlet.
9	Then he nailed the plank down again and put his tools in his bag, and came downstairs.
8	The cat family had quite recovered.
9	They invited him to stay to dinner.
9	The dumpling had been peeled off Tom Kitten and made separately into a bag pudding, with currants in it to hide the smuts.
9	They had been obliged to put Tom Kitten into a hot bath to get the butter off.
0	John Joiner smelt the pudding; but he regretted that he had not time to stay to dinner, because he had just finished making a wheelbarrow for Miss Potter, and she had ordered two hen coops.
9	And when I was going to the post late in the afternoon--I looked up the land from the corner, and I saw Mr. Samuel Whiskers and his wife on the run, with big bundles on a little wheelbarrow, which looked very much like mine.
9	They were just turning in at the gate to the barn of Farmer Potatoes.
9	Samuel Whiskers was puffing and out of breath.
5	Anna Maria was still arguing in shrill tones.
9	She seemed to know her way, and she seemed to have a quantity of luggage.
9	I am sure _I_ never gave her leave to borrow my wheelbarrow!
9	They went into the barn and hauled their parcels with a bit of string to the top of the haymow.
9	After that, there were no more rats for a long time at Tabitha Twitchit's.
5	As for Farmer Potatoes, he has been driven nearly distracted.
9	There are rats, and rats, and rats in his barn!
9	They eat up the chicken food, and steal the oats and bran, and make holes in the meal bags.
9	And they are all descended from Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Whiskers-- children and grandchildren and great-great-grandchildren.
9	There is no end to them!
9	Moppet and Mittens have grown up into very good rat-catchers.
9	They go out rat-catching in the village, and they find plenty of employment.
9	They charge so much a dozen and earn their living very comfortably.
9	They hang up the rats' tails in a row on the barn door, to show how many they have caught--dozens and dozens of them.
7	But Tom Kitten has always been afraid of a rat; he never durst face anything that is bigger than--
9	A Mouse.
9	Once upon a time there was a village shop.
9	The name over the window was "Ginger and Pickles."
9	It was a little small shop just the right size for Dolls-- Lucinda and Jane Doll-cook always bought their groceries at Ginger and Pickles.
9	The counter inside was a convenient height for rabbits.
9	Ginger and Pickles sold red spotty pocket handkerchiefs at a penny three farthings.
9	They also sold sugar, and snuff and galoshes.
9	In fact, although it was such a small shop it sold nearly everything--except a few things that you want in a hurry--like bootlaces, hair- pins and mutton chops.
9	Ginger and Pickles were the people who kept the shop.
9	Ginger was a yellow tomcat, and Pickles was a terrier.
7	The rabbits were always a little bit afraid of Pickles.
7	The shop was also patronized by mice--only the mice were rather afraid of Ginger.
9	Ginger usually requested Pickles to serve them, because he said it made his mouth water.
2	"I cannot bear," said he, "to see them going out at the door carrying their little parcels."
9	"I have the same feeling about rats," replied Pickles, "but it would never do to eat our customers; they would leave us and go to Tabitha Twitchit's."
0	"On the contrary, they would go nowhere," replied Ginger gloomily.
9	(Tabitha Twitchit kept the only other shop in the village.
9	She did not give credit.)
9	But there is no money in what is called the "till."
9	Ginger and Pickles gave unlimited credit.
9	Now the meaning of "credit" is this--when a customer buys a bar of soap, instead of the customer pulling out a purse and paying for it --she says she will pay another time.
9	And Pickles makes a low bow and says, "With pleasure, madam," and it is written down in a book.
7	The customers come again and again, and buy quantities, in spite of being afraid of Ginger and Pickles.
9	The customers came in crowds every day and bought quantities, especially the toffee customers.
9	But there was always no money; they never paid for as much as a penny- worth of peppermints.
9	But the sales were enormous, ten times as large as Tabitha Twitchit's.
9	As there was always no money, Ginger and Pickles were obliged to eat their own goods.
9	Pickles ate biscuits and Ginger ate a dried haddock.
9	They ate them by candle- light after the shop was closed.
7	"It is very uncomfortable, I am afraid I shall be summoned.
0	I have tried in vain to get a license upon credit at the Post Office;" said Pickles.
9	"The place is full of policemen.
9	I met one as I was coming home.
9	"Let us send in the bill again to Samuel Whiskers, Ginger, he owes 22/9 for bacon."
9	"I do not believe that he intends to pay at all," replied Ginger.
9	When it came to Jan. 1st there was still no money, and Pickles was unable to buy a dog license.
7	"It is very unpleasant, I am afraid of the police," said Pickles.
9	"It is your own fault for being a terrier; _I_ do not require a license, and neither does Kep, the Collie dog."
2	"And I feel sure that Anna Maria pockets things--
9	"Where are all the cream crackers?"
9	"You have eaten them yourself." replied Ginger.
9	Ginger and Pickles retired into the back parlor.
9	They did accounts.
9	They added up sums and sums, and sums.
9	"Samuel Whiskers has run up a bill as long as his tail; he has had an ounce and three- quarters of snuff since October.
9	"What is seven pounds of butter at 1/3, and a stick of sealing wax and four matches?"
9	"Send in all the bills again to everybody `with compliments,'" replied Ginger.
5	Pickles nearly had a fit, he barked and he barked and made little rushes.
5	"Bite him, Pickles! bite him!" spluttered Ginger behind a sugar barrel, "he's only a German doll!"
9	The policeman went on writing in his notebook; twice he put his pencil in his mouth, and once he dipped it in the treacle.
5	Pickles barked till he was hoarse.
9	But still the policeman took no notice.
9	He had bead eyes, and his helmet was sewed on with stitches.
9	After a time they heard a noise in the shop, as if something had been pushed in at the door.
9	They came out of the back parlor.
9	There was an envelope lying on the counter, and a policeman writing in a notebook!
9	At length on his last little rush--Pickles found that the shop was empty.
9	The policeman had disappeared.
9	But the envelope remained.
9	"Do you think that he has gone to fetch a real live policeman?
7	I am afraid it is a summons," said Pickles.
9	"No," replied Ginger, who had opened the envelope, "it is the rates and taxes, 3 pounds 19 11 3/4." [pounds are British money, the 19 is schillings, and then pence]
9	They put up the shutters, and left.
9	But they have not removed from the neighborhood.
9	In fact some people wish they had gone further.
9	Ginger is living in the warren [game preserve for rabbits].
9	I do not know what occupation he pursues; he looks stout and comfortable.
9	Pickles is at present a game- keeper.
9	After a time Mr. John Dormouse and his daughter began to sell peppermints and candles.
9	But they did not keep "self- fitting sixes"; and it takes five mice to carry one seven inch candle.
9	The closing of the shop caused great inconvenience.
9	Tabitha Twitchit immediately raised the price of everything a halfpenny; and she continued to refuse to give credit.
9	Of course there are the tradesmen's carts--the butcher, the fishman and Timothy Baker.
9	But a person cannot live on "seed wigs" and sponge cake and butter buns--not even when the sponge cake is as good as Timothy's!
9	And Miss Dormouse refused to take back the ends when they were brought back to her with complaints.
9	And when Mr. John Dormouse was complained to, he stayed in bed, and would say nothing but "very snug;" which is not the way to carry on a retail business.
9	Besides--the candles which they sell behave very strangely in warm weather.
8	So everybody was pleased when Sally Henny Penny sent out a printed poster to say that she was going to reopen the shop--"Henny's Opening Sale!
9	Grand cooperative Jumble!
9	Penny's penny prices!
9	Come buy, come try, come buy!"
9	The poster really was most 'ticing.
9	There was a rush upon the opening day.
9	The shop was crammed with customers, and there were crowds of mice upon the biscuit cannisters.
5	Sally Henny Penny gets rather flustered when she tries to count out change, and she insists on being paid cash; but she is quite harmless.
9	And she has laid in a remarkable assortment of bargains.
8	There is something to please everybody.
9	Once upon a time there was a little fat comfortable grey squirrel, called Timmy Tiptoes.
9	He had a nest thatched with leaves in the top of a tall tree; and he had a little squirrel wife called Goody.
8	Timmy Tiptoes sat out, enjoying the breeze; he whisked his tail and chuckled--"Little wife Goody, the nuts are ripe; we must lay up a store for winter and spring."
9	Goody Tiptoes was busy pushing moss under the thatch--"The nest is so snug, we shall be sound asleep all winter."
9	"Then we shall wake up all the thinner, when there is nothing to eat in spring- time," replied prudent Timothy.
9	When Timmy and Goody Tiptoes came to the nut thicket, they found other squirrels were there already.
9	Timmy took off his jacket and hung it on a twig; they worked away quietly by themselves.
9	Every day they made several journeys and picked quantities of nuts.
9	They carried them away in bags, and stored them in several hollow stumps near the tree where they had built their nest.
9	When these stumps were full, they began to empty the bags into a hole high up a tree, that had belonged to a woodpecker; the nuts rattled down--down--down inside.
9	"How shall you ever get them out again?
1	It is like a money box!" said Goody.
8	"I shall be much thinner before springtime, my love," said Timmy Tiptoes, peeping into the hole.
9	They did collect quantities-- because they did not lose them!
9	Squirrels who bury their nuts in the ground lose more than half, because they cannot remember the place.
9	The most forgetful squirrel in the wood was called Silvertail.
9	He began to dig, and he could not remember.
9	And then he dug again and found some nuts that did not belong to him; and there was a fight.
9	And other squirrels began to dig,--the whole wood was in commotion!
9	Unfortunately, just at this time a flock of little birds flew by, from bush to bush, searching for green caterpillars and spiders.
9	There were several sorts of little birds, twittering different songs.
5	The first one sang--"Who's bin digging-up MY nuts?
5	Who's-been- digging-up MY nuts?"
5	And another sang--"Little bita bread and-NO-cheese!
5	Little bit-a- bread an'-NO-cheese!"
9	The squirrels followed and listened.
5	The first little bird flew into the bush where Timmy and Goody Tiptoes were quietly tying up their bags, and it sang--"Who's-bin digging-up MY nuts?
5	Who's been digging-up MY-nuts?"
9	Timmy Tiptoes went on with his work without replying; indeed, the little bird did not expect an answer.
9	It was only singing its natural song, and it meant nothing at all.
5	But when the other squirrels heard that song, they rushed upon Timmy Tiptoes and cuffed and scratched him, and upset his bag of nuts.
7	The innocent little bird which had caused all the mischief, flew away in a fright!
5	Timmy rolled over and over, and then turned tail and fled towards his nest, followed by a crowd of squirrels shouting-- "Who's-been digging-up MY-nuts?"
9	They caught him and dragged him up the very same tree, where there was the little round hole, and they pushed him in.
9	The hole was much too small for Timmy Tiptoes' figure.
9	They squeezed him dreadfully, it was a wonder they did not break his ribs.
5	"We will leave him here till he confesses," said Silvertail Squirrel and he shouted into the hole--"Who's- been-digging-up MY-nuts?"
9	Timmy Tiptoes made no reply; he had tumbled down inside the tree, upon half a peck of nuts belonging to himself.
9	Goody Tiptoes picked up the nut bags and went home.
9	She made a cup of tea for Timmy; but he didn't come and didn't come.
7	Goody Tiptoes passed a lonely and unhappy night.
9	Next morning she ventured back to the nut bushes to look for him; but the other unkind squirrels drove her away.
9	She wandered all over the wood, calling--
0	"Timmy Tiptoes!
0	Timmy Tip- toes!
0	Oh, where is Timmy Tiptoes?"
9	In the meantime Timmy Tiptoes came to his senses.
0	Timmy coughed and groaned, because his ribs hurted him.
9	There was a chirpy noise, and a small striped Chipmunk appeared with a night light, and hoped he felt better?
8	It was most kind to Timmy Tiptoes; it lent him its nightcap; and the house was full of provisions.
9	The Chipmunk explained that it had rained nuts through the top of the tree--"Besides, I found a few buried!"
8	It laughed and chuckled when it heard Timmy's story.
9	While Timmy was confined to bed, it 'ticed him to eat quantities --"But how shall I ever get out through that hole unless I thin myself?
7	My wife will be anxious!"
9	"Just another nut--or two nuts; let me crack them for you," said the Chipmunk.
9	Timmy Tiptoes grew fatter and fatter!
9	Now Goody Tiptoes had set to work again by herself.
9	She did not put any more nuts into the woodpecker's hole, because she had always doubted how they could be got out again.
9	She hid them under a tree root; they rattled down, down, down.
9	Once when Goody emptied an extra big bagful, there was a decided squeak; and next time Goody brought another bagful, a little striped Chipmunk scrambled out in a hurry.
0	"It is getting perfectly full-up downstairs; the sitting room is full, and they are rolling along the passage; and my husband, Chippy Hackee, has run away and left me.
9	What is the explanation of these showers of nuts?"
9	"I am sure I beg your pardon; I did not know that anybody lived here," said Mrs. Goody Tiptoes; "but where is Chippy Hackee?
0	My husband, Timmy Tiptoes, has run away too."
9	"I know where Chippy is; a little bird told me," said Mrs. Chippy Hackee.
9	She led the way to the woodpecker's tree, and they listened at the hole.
8	Down below there was a noise of nutcrackers, and a fat squirrel voice and a thin squirrel voice were singing together--
9	"My little old man and I fell out, How shall we bring this matter about?
9	Bring it about as well as you can, And get you gone, you little old man!"
9	"You could squeeze in, through that little round hole," said Goody Tiptoes.
9	"Yes, I could," said the Chipmunk, "but my husband, Chippy Hackee, bites!"
9	Down below there was a noise of cracking nuts and nibbling; and then the fat squirrel voice and the thin squirrel voice sang--
9	"For the diddlum day Day diddle durn di!
9	Day diddle diddle dum day!"
9	Then Goody peeped in at the hole, and called down--"Timmy Tiptoes!
5	Oh fie, Timmy Tiptoes!"
9	And Timmy replied, "Is that you, Goody Tiptoes?
9	Why, certainly!"
8	He came up and kissed Goody through the hole; but he was so fat that he could not get out.
8	Chippy Hackee was not too fat, but he did not want to come; he stayed down below and chuckled.
9	And so it went on for a fort- night; till a big wind blew off the top of the tree, and opened up the hole and let in the rain.
9	Then Timmy Tiptoes came out, and went home with an umbrella.
9	But Chippy Hackee continued to camp out for another week, although it was uncomfortable.
9	At last a large bear came walking through the wood.
9	Perhaps he also was looking for nuts; he seemed to be sniffing around.
7	Chippy Hackee went home in a hurry!
0	And when Chippy Hackee got home, he found he had caught a cold in his head; and he was more uncomfortable still.
9	And now Timmy and Goody Tiptoes keep their nut store fastened up with a little padlock.
9	And whenever that little bird sees the Chipmunks, he sings--"Who's-been-digging- up MY-nuts?
9	Who's been dig- ging-up MY-nuts?"
9	But nobody ever answers!
9	Once upon a time there were four little Rabbits, and their names were-- Flopsy, Mopsy, Cotton-tail, and Peter.
9	They lived with their Mother in a sand-bank, underneath the root of a very big fir-tree.
9	"Now, my dears," said old Mrs. Rabbit one morning, "you may go into the fields or down the lane, but don't go into Mr. McGregor's garden: your Father had an accident there; he was put in a pie by Mrs. McGregor."
9	"Now run along, and don't get into mischief.
9	I am going out."
9	Then old Mrs. Rabbit took a basket and her umbrella, and went through the wood to the baker's.
9	She bought a loaf of brown bread and five currant buns.
9	Flopsy, Mopsy, and Cotton-tail, who were good little bunnies, went down the lane to gather blackberries;
9	But Peter, who was very naughty, ran straight away to Mr. McGregor's garden, and squeezed under the gate!
9	First he ate some lettuces and some French beans; and then he ate some radishes;
0	And then, feeling rather sick, he went to look for some parsley.
1	But round the end of a cucumber frame, whom should he meet but Mr. McGregor!
5	Mr. McGregor was on his hands and knees planting out young cabbages, but he jumped up and ran after Peter, waving a rake and calling out, "Stop thief."
7	Peter was most dreadfully frightened; he rushed all over the garden, for he had forgotten the way back to the gate.
9	He lost one of his shoes among the cabbages, and the other shoe amongst the potatoes.
9	After losing them, he ran on four legs and went faster, so that I think he might have got away altogether if he had not unfortunately run into a gooseberry net, and got caught by the large buttons on his jacket.
9	It was a blue jacket with brass buttons, quite new.
0	Peter gave himself up for lost, and shed big tears; but his sobs were overheard by some friendly sparrows, who flew to him in great excitement, and implored him to exert himself.
9	Mr. McGregor came up with a sieve, which he intended to pop upon the top of Peter; but Peter wriggled out just in time, leaving his jacket behind him.
9	And rushed into the toolshed, and jumped into a can.
9	It would have been a beautiful thing to hide in, if it had not had so much water in it.
9	Mr. McGregor was quite sure that Peter was somewhere in the toolshed, perhaps hidden underneath a flower- pot.
9	He began to turn them over carefully, looking under each.
9	Presently Peter sneezed-- "Kertyschoo!"
9	Mr. McGregor was after him in no time,
9	And tried to put his foot upon Peter, who jumped out of a window, upsetting three plants.
9	The window was too small for Mr. McGregor, and he was tired of running after Peter.
9	He went back to his work.
7	Peter sat down to rest; he was out of breath and trembling with fright, and he had not the least idea which way to go.
9	Also he was very damp with sitting in that can.
9	After a time he began to wander about, going lippity--lippity--not very fast, and looking all around.
9	He found a door in a wall; but it was locked, and there was no room for a fat little rabbit to squeeze underneath.
9	An old mouse was running in and out over the stone doorstep, carrying peas and beans to her family in the wood.
9	Peter asked her the way to the gate, but she had such a large pea in her mouth that she could not answer.
9	She only shook her head at him.
0	Peter began to cry.
0	Then he tried to find his way straight across the garden, but he became more and more puzzled.
9	Presently, he came to a pond where Mr. McGregor filled his water-cans.
9	A white cat was staring at some goldfish; she sat very, very still, but now and then the tip of her tail twitched as if it were alive.
9	Peter thought it best to go away without speaking to her; he has heard about cats from his cousin, little Benjamin Bunny.
1	He went back towards the toolshed, but suddenly, quite close to him, he heard the noise of a hoe-- scr-r-ritch, scratch, scratch, scritch.
7	Peter scuttered underneath the bushes.
9	But presently, as nothing happened, he came out, and climbed upon a wheelbarrow, and peeped over.
9	The first thing he saw was Mr. McGregor hoeing onions.
9	His back was turned towards Peter, and beyond him was the gate!
9	Peter got down very quietly off the wheelbarrow, and started running as fast as he could go, along a straight walk behind some black-currant bushes.
9	Mr. McGregor caught sight of him at the corner, but Peter did not care.
1	He slipped underneath the gate, and was safe at last in the wood outside the garden.
9	Mr. McGregor hung up the little jacket and the shoes for a scare-crow to frighten the blackbirds.
9	Peter never stopped running or looked behind him till he got home to the big fir-tree.
9	He was so tired that he flopped down upon the nice soft sand on the floor of the rabbit-hole, and shut his eyes.
9	His mother was busy cooking; she wondered what he had done with his clothes.
1	It was the second little jacket and pair of shoes that Peter had lost in a fortnight!
0	I am sorry to say that Peter was not very well during the evening.
9	His mother put him to bed, and made some camomile tea; and she gave a dose of it to Peter!
9	"One table-spoonful to be taken at bed-time."
9	But Flopsy, Mopsy, and Cotton-tail had bread and milk and blackberries for supper.
9	Pussy-cat sits by the fire--how should she be fair?
9	In walks the little dog--says "Pussy are you there?
9	How do you do Mistress Pussy?
9	Mistress Pussy, how do you do?"
8	"I thank you kindly, little dog, I fare as well as you!" [Old Rhyme]
9	Once upon a time there was a Pussy-cat called Ribby, who invited a little dog called Duchess to tea.
8	"Come in good time, my dear Duchess," said Ribby's letter, "and we will have something so very nice.
9	I am baking it in a pie-dish--a pie-dish with a pink rim.
8	You never tasted anything so good!
8	And YOU shall eat it all! _I_ will eat muffins, my dear Duchess!" wrote Ribby.
9	"I will come very punctually, my dear Ribby," wrote Duchess; and then at the end she added--"I hope it isn't mouse?"
9	And then she thought that did not look quite polite; so she scratched out "isn't mouse" and changed it to "I hope it will be fine," and she gave her letter to the postman.
9	But she thought a great deal about Ribby's pie, and she read Ribby's letter over and over again.
7	"I am dreadfully afraid it WILL be mouse!" said Duchess to herself--"I really couldn't, COULDN'T eat mouse pie.
7	And I shall have to eat it, because it is a party.
9	And MY pie was going to be veal and ham.
9	A pink and white pie-dish! and so is mine; just like Ribby's dishes; they were both bought at Tabitha Twitchit's."
9	Duchess went into her larder and took the pie off a shelf and looked at it.
8	"Oh what a good idea!
8	Why shouldn't I rush along and put my pie into Ribby's oven when Ribby isn't there?"
9	Ribby in the meantime had received Duchess's answer, and as soon as she was sure that the little dog would come--she popped HER pie into the oven.
9	There were two ovens, one above the other; some other knobs and handles were only ornamental and not intended to open.
9	Ribby put the pie into the lower oven; the door was very stiff.
9	"The top oven bakes too quickly," said Ribby to herself.
9	Ribby put on some coal and swept up the hearth.
9	Then she went out with a can to the well, for water to fill up the kettle.
9	Then she began to set the room in order, for it was the sitting-room as well as the kitchen.
9	When Ribby had laid the table she went out down the field to the farm, to fetch milk and butter.
9	When she came back, she peeped into the bottom oven; the pie looked very comfortable.
9	Ribby put on her shawl and bonnet and went out again with a basket, to the village shop to buy a packet of tea, a pound of lump sugar, and a pot of marmalade.
9	And just at the same time, Duchess came out of HER house, at the other end of the village.
9	Ribby met Duchess half-way down the street, also carrying a basket, covered with a cloth.
9	They only bowed to one another; they did not speak, because they were going to have a party.
9	As soon as Duchess had got round the corner out of sight--she simply ran!
9	Straight away to Ribby's house!
8	Ribby went into the shop and bought what she required, and came out, after a pleasant gossip with Cousin Tabitha Twitchit.
9	Ribby went on to Timothy Baker's and bought the muffins.
9	Then she went home.
9	There seemed to be a sort of scuffling noise in the back passage, as she was coming in at the front door.
9	But there was nobody there.
9	Duchess in the meantime, had slipped out at the back door.
1	"It is a very odd thing that Ribby's pie was NOT in the oven when I put mine in!
1	And I can't find it anywhere; I have looked all over the house.
9	I put MY pie into a nice hot oven at the top.
9	I could not turn any of the other handles; I think that they are all shams," said Duchess, "but I wish I could have removed the pie made of mouse!
9	I cannot think what she has done with it?
1	I heard Ribby coming and I had to run out by the back door!"
9	Duchess went home and brushed her beautiful black coat; and then she picked a bunch of flowers in her garden as a present for Ribby; and passed the time until the clock struck four.
9	Ribby--having assured herself by careful search that there was really no one hiding in the cupboard or in the larder--went upstairs to change her dress.
9	She came downstairs again, and made the tea, and put the teapot on the hob.
9	She peeped again into the BOTTOM oven, the pie had become a lovely brown, and it was steaming hot.
9	She sat down before the fire to wait for the little dog.
8	"I am glad I used the BOTTOM oven," said Ribby, "the top one would certainly have been very much too hot."
9	Very punctually at four o'clock, Duchess started to go to the party.
9	At a quarter past four to the minute, there came a most genteel little tap-tappity.
9	"Is Mrs. Ribston at home?" inquired Duchess in the porch.
8	"Come in! and how do you do, my dear Duchess?" cried Ribby.
8	"I hope I see you well?"
8	"Quite well, I thank you, and how do YOU do, my dear Ribby?" said Duchess.
8	"I've brought you some flowers; what a delicious smell of pie!"
8	"Oh, what lovely flowers!
8	Yes, it is mouse and bacon!"
9	"I think it wants another five minutes," said Ribby.
9	"Just a shade longer; I will pour out the tea, while we wait.
9	Do you take sugar, my dear Duchess?"
8	"Oh yes, please! my dear Ribby; and may I have a lump upon my nose?"
8	"With pleasure, my dear Duchess."
9	Duchess sat up with the sugar on her nose and sniffed--
8	"How good that pie smells!
8	I do love veal and ham--I mean to say mouse and bacon--"
9	She dropped the sugar in confusion, and had to go hunting under the tea- table, so did not see which oven Ribby opened in order to get out the pie.
9	Ribby set the pie upon the table; there was a very savoury smell.
9	Duchess came out from under the table-cloth munching sugar, and sat up on a chair.
9	"I will first cut the pie for you; I am going to have muffin and marmalade," said Ribby.
9	"I think"--(thought Duchess to herself)--"I THINK it would be wiser if I helped myself to pie; though Ribby did not seem to notice anything when she was cutting it.
9	What very small fine pieces it has cooked into!
9	I did not remember that I had minced it up so fine; I suppose this is a quicker oven than my own."
9	The pie-dish was emptying rapidly!
9	Duchess had had four helps already, and was fumbling with the spoon.
8	"A little more bacon, my dear Duchess?" said Ribby.
8	"Thank you, my dear Ribby; I was only feeling for the patty-pan."
9	"The patty-pan? my dear Duchess?"
9	"The patty pan that held up the pie-crust," said Duchess, blushing under her black coat.
9	"Oh, I didn't put one in, my dear Duchess," said Ribby; "I don't think that it is necessary in pies made of mouse."
1	"There isn't a patty-pan," said Ribby, looking perplexed.
1	"Yes, indeed, my dear Ribby; where can it have gone to?" said Duchess.
7	Duchess looked very much alarmed, and continued to scoop the inside of the pie-dish.
9	"I have only four patty-pans, and they are all in the cupboard."
7	Oh, my dear Ribby, I do feel so ill!"
9	"It is impossible, my dear Duchess; there was not a patty-pan."
7	"Yes there WAS, my dear Ribby, I am sure I have swallowed it!"
9	"Let me prop you up with a pillow, my dear Duchess; where do you think you feel it?"
7	"Oh I do feel so ill ALL OVER me, my dear Ribby."
9	"Shall I run for the doctor?"
9	"Oh yes, yes! fetch Dr. Maggotty, my dear Ribby: he is a Pie himself, he will certainly understand."
9	Ribby settled Duchess in an armchair before the fire, and went out and hurried to the village to look for the doctor.
9	She found him at the smithy.
9	Ribby explained that her guest had swallowed a patty-pan.
7	Dr. Maggotty hopped so fast that Ribby had to run.
9	It was most conspicuous.
9	All the village could see that Ribby was fetching the doctor.
7	But while Ribby had been hunting for the doctor--a curious thing had happened to Duchess, who had been left by herself, sitting before the fire, sighing and groaning and feeling very unhappy.
1	"How COULD I have swallowed it! such a large thing as a patty-pan!"
0	She sat down again, and stared mournfully at the grate.
9	The fire crackled and danced, and something sizz-z-zled!
1	Duchess started!
1	She opened the door of the TOP oven;--out came a rich steamy flavour of veal and ham, and there stood a fine brown pie,-- and through a hole in the top of the pie-crust there was a glimpse of a little tin patty-pan!
8	Duchess drew a long breath--
1	"Then I must have been eating MOUSE!
9	. . .
9	. . .
9	But perhaps I should feel worse if I had really swallowed a patty-pan!"
7	Duchess reflected--"What a very awkward thing to have to explain to Ribby!
9	I think I will put MY pie in the back-yard and say nothing about it.
9	When I go home, I will run round and take it away."
9	She put it outside the back-door, and sat down again by the fire, and shut her eyes; when Ribby arrived with the doctor, she seemed fast asleep.
8	"I am feeling very much better," said Duchess, waking up with a jump.
8	"I am truly glad to hear it!
9	He has brought you a pill, my dear Duchess!"
9	"I think I should feel QUITE well if he only felt my pulse," said Duchess, backing away from the magpie, who sidled up with something in his beak.
9	"It is only a bread pill, you had much better take it; drink a little milk, my dear Duchess!"
9	"I am feeling very much better, my dear Ribby," said Duchess.
9	"Do you not think that I had better go home before it gets dark?"
9	"Perhaps it might be wise, my dear Duchess."
8	Ribby and Duchess said good-bye affectionately, and Duchess started home.
9	Half-way up the lane she stopped and looked back; Ribby had gone in and shut her door.
9	Duchess slipped through the fence, and ran round to the back of Ribby's house, and peeped into the yard.
9	Upon the roof of the pig-stye sat Dr. Maggotty and three jackdaws.
9	The jackdaws were eating piecrust, and the magpie was drinking gravy out of a patty-pan.
1	When Ribby came out for a pailful of water to wash up the tea-things, she found a pink and white pie-dish lying smashed in the middle of the yard.
1	Ribby stared with amazement-- "Did you ever see the like! so there really WAS a patty-pan?
9	. . .
1	But MY patty-pans are all in the kitchen cupboard.
1	Well I never did!
9	. . .
9	Next time I want to give a party--I will invite Cousin Tabitha Twitchit!"
9	Once upon a time there was a frog called Mr. Jeremy Fisher; he lived in a little damp house amongst the buttercups at the edge of a pond.
9	The water was all slippy-sloppy in the larder and in the back passage.
8	But Mr. Jeremy liked getting his feet wet; nobody ever scolded him, and he never caught a cold!
8	He was quite pleased when he looked out and saw large drops of rain, splashing in the pond--
9	"I will get some worms and go fishing and catch a dish of minnows for my dinner," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.
9	"If I catch more than five fish, I will invite my friends Mr. Alderman Ptolemy Tortoise and Sir Isaac Newton.
9	The Alderman, however, eats salad."
9	Mr. Jeremy put on a mackintosh, and a pair of shiny galoshes; he took his rod and basket, and set off with enormous hops to the place where he kept his boat.
9	The boat was round and green, and very like the other lily-leaves.
9	It was tied to a water-plant in the middle of the pond.
9	Mr. Jeremy took a reed pole, and pushed the boat out into open water.
9	"I know a good place for minnows," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.
9	Mr. Jeremy stuck his pole into the mud and fastened the boat to it.
9	Then he settled himself cross- legged and arranged his fishing tackle.
9	He had the dearest little red float.
9	His rod was a tough stalk of grass, his line was a fine long white horse-hair, and he tied a little wriggling worm at the end.
9	The rain trickled down his back, and for nearly an hour he stared at the float.
2	"This is getting tiresome, I think I should like some lunch," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.
9	He punted back again amongst the water-plants, and took some lunch out of his basket.
9	"I will eat a butterfly sandwich, and wait till the shower is over," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.
9	A great big water-beetle came up underneath the lily leaf and tweaked the toe of one of his galoshes.
9	Mr. Jeremy crossed his legs up shorter, out of reach, and went on eating his sandwich.
9	Once or twice something moved about with a rustle and a splash amongst the rushes at the side of the pond.
7	"I trust that is not a rat," said Mr. Jeremy Fisher; "I think I had better get away from here."
9	Mr. Jeremy shoved the boat out again a little way, and dropped in the bait.
9	There was a bite almost directly; the float gave a tremendous bobbit!
1	"A minnow! a minnow!
1	I have him by the nose!" cried Mr. Jeremy Fisher, jerking up his rod.
1	But what a horrible surprise!
9	Instead of a smooth fat minnow, Mr. Jeremy landed little Jack Sharp, the stickleback, covered with spines!
9	Then he jumped back into the water.
1	A great big enormous trout came up--ker-pflop-p-p-p! with a splash-- and it seized Mr. Jeremy with a snap, "Ow!
1	Ow!
1	Ow!"--and then it turned and dived down to the bottom of the pond!
2	But the trout was so displeased with the taste of the mackintosh, that in less than half a minute it spat him out again; and the only thing it swallowed was Mr. Jeremy's galoshes.
9	Mr. Jeremy bounced up to the surface of the water, like a cork and the bubbles out of a soda water bottle; and he swam with all his might to the edge of the pond.
7	He scrambled out on the first bank he came to, and he hopped home across the meadow with his mackintosh all in tatters.
8	"What a mercy that was not a pike!" said Mr. Jeremy Fisher.
9	He put some sticking plaster on his fingers, and his friends both came to dinner.
9	He could not offer them fish, but he had something else in his larder.
9	Sir Isaac Newton wore his black and gold waistcoat.
9	And Mr. Alderman Ptolemy Tortoise brought a salad with him in a string bag.
9	And instead of a nice dish of minnows, they had a roasted grasshopper with lady-bird sauce, which frogs consider a beautiful treat; but _I_ think it must have been nasty!
9	Once upon a time there was an old pig called Aunt Pettitoes.
9	She had eight of a family: four little girl pigs, called Cross-patch, Suck-suck, Yock-yock and Spot; and four little boy pigs, called Alexander, Pigling Bland, Chin-Chin and Stumpy.
9	Stumpy had had an accident to his tail.
8	The eight little pigs had very fine appetites--"Yus, yus, yus! they eat and indeed they DO eat!" said Aunt Pettitoes, looking at her family with pride.
7	Suddenly there were fearful squeals; Alexander had squeezed inside the hoops of the pig trough and stuck.
9	Aunt Pettitoes and I dragged him out by the hind legs.
7	Chin-chin was already in disgrace; it was washing day, and he had eaten a piece of soap.
1	And presently in a basket of clean clothes, we found another dirty little pig--"Tchut, tut, tut! whichever is this?" grunted Aunt Pettitoes.
9	Now all the pig family are pink, or pink with black spots, but this pig child was smutty black all over; when it had been popped into a tub, it proved to be Yock-yock.
9	I went into the garden; there I found Cross-patch and Suck-suck rooting up carrots.
9	I whipped them myself and led them out by the ears.
5	Cross-patch tried to bite me.
9	"Aunt Pettitoes, Aunt Pettitoes! you are a worthy person, but your family is not well brought up.
9	Every one of them has been in mischief except Spot and Pigling Bland."
9	"And they drink bucketfuls of milk; I shall have to get another cow!
9	Good little Spot shall stay at home to do the housework; but the others must go.
9	Four little boy pigs and four little girl pigs are too many altogether."
0	"Yus, yus, yus," said Aunt Pettitoes, "there will be more to eat without them."
9	So Chin-chin and Suck-suck went away in a wheel-barrow, and Stumpy, Yock-yock and Cross- patch rode away in a cart.
9	And the other two little boy pigs, Pigling Bland and Alexander went to market.
9	We brushed their coats, we curled their tails and washed their little faces, and wished them good bye in the yard.
0	Aunt Pettitoes wiped her eyes with a large pocket handkerchief, then she wiped Pigling Bland's nose and shed tears; then she wiped Alexander's nose and shed tears; then she passed the handkerchief to Spot.
0	Aunt Pettitoes sighed and grunted, and addressed those little pigs as follows--
9	"Now Pigling Bland, son Pigling Bland, you must go to market.
9	Take your brother Alexander by the hand.
9	Mind your Sunday clothes, and remember to blow your nose" --(Aunt Pettitoes passed round the handkerchief again)--"beware of traps, hen roosts, bacon and eggs; always walk upon your hind legs."
0	Pigling Bland who was a sedate little pig, looked solemnly at his mother, a tear trickled down his cheek.
8	Aunt Pettitoes turned to the other--"Now son Alexander take the hand"--"Wee, wee, wee!" giggled Alexander--"take the hand of your brother Pigling Bland, you must go to market.
9	Mind--" "Wee, wee, wee!" interrupted Alexander again.
9	"You put me out," said Aunt Pettitoes--"Observe signposts and milestones; do not gobble herring bones--" "And remember," said I impressively, "if you once cross the county boundary you cannot come back.
9	Alexander, you are not attending.
9	Here are two licenses permitting two pigs to go to market in Lancashire.
9	Attend Alexander.
9	I have had no end of trouble in getting these papers from the policeman."
0	Pigling Bland listened gravely; Alexander was hopelessly volatile.
9	I pinned the papers, for safety, inside their waistcoat pockets; Aunt Pettitoes gave to each a little bundle, and eight conversation peppermints with appropriate moral sentiments in screws of paper.
9	Then they started.
9	Pigling Bland and Alexander trotted along steadily for a mile; at least Pigling Bland did.
9	Alexander made the road half as long again by skipping from side to side.
8	He danced about and pinched his brother, singing--
8	"This pig went to market, this pig stayed at home, "This pig had a bit of meat--
9	let's see what they have given US for dinner, Pigling?"
9	Pigling Bland and Alexander sat down and untied their bundles.
9	Alexander gobbled up his dinner in no time; he had already eaten all his own peppermints--"Give me one of yours, please, Pigling?"
9	"But I wish to preserve them for emergencies," said Pigling Bland doubtfully.
8	Alexander went into squeals of laughter.
5	Then he pricked Pigling with the pin that had fastened his pig paper; and when Pigling slapped him he dropped the pin, and tried to take Pigling's pin, and the papers got mixed up.
5	Pigling Bland reproved Alexander.
8	But presently they made it up again, and trotted away together, singing--
9	"Tom, Tom the piper's son, stole a pig and away he ran!
9	"But all the tune that he could play, was `Over the hills and far away!'"
9	"What's that, young Sirs?
9	Stole a pig?
9	Where are your licenses?" said the policeman.
9	They had nearly run against him round a corner.
9	Pigling Bland pulled out his paper; Alexander, after fumbling, handed over something scrumply--
1	"To 2 1/2 oz. conversation sweeties at three farthings"--"What's this? this ain't a license?"
7	Alexander's nose lengthened visibly, he had lost it.
7	"I had one, indeed I had, Mr. Policeman!"
9	"It's not likely they let you start without.
9	I am passing the farm.
9	You may walk with me."
9	"Can I come back too?" inquired Pigling Bland.
9	"I see no reason, young Sir; your paper is all right."
7	Pigling Bland did not like going on alone, and it was beginning to rain.
9	But it is unwise to argue with the police; he gave his brother a peppermint, and watched him out of sight.
0	To conclude the adventures of Alexander--the policeman sauntered up to the house about tea time, followed by a damp subdued little pig.
9	I disposed of Alexander in the neighborhood; he did fairly well when he had settled down.
0	Pigling Bland went on alone dejectedly; he came to cross roads and a sign-post--"To Market-town 5 miles," "Over the Hills, 4 miles," "To Pettitoes Farm, 3 miles."
1	Pigling Bland was shocked, there was little hope of sleeping in Market Town, and tomorrow was the hiring fair; it was deplorable to think how much time had been wasted by the frivolity of Alexander.
9	He glanced wistfully along the road towards the hills, and then set off walking obediently the other way, buttoning up his coat against the rain.
9	"I wish I could have a little garden and grow potatoes," said Pigling Bland.
1	He put his cold hand in his pocket and felt his paper, he put his other hand in his other pocket and felt another paper--Alexander's!
9	He took a wrong turn--several wrong turns, and was quite lost.
9	It grew dark, the wind whistled, the trees creaked and groaned.
7	Pigling Bland became frightened and cried "Wee, wee, wee!
7	I can't find my way home!"
9	After an hour's wandering he got out of the wood; the moon shone through the clouds, and Pigling Bland saw a country that was new to him.
9	The road crossed a moor; below was a wide valley with a river twinkling in the moonlight, and beyond --in misty distance--lay the hills.
0	He saw a small wooden hut, made his way to it, and crept inside --"I am afraid it IS a hen house, but what can I do?" said Pigling Bland, wet and cold and quite tired out.
8	"Bacon and eggs, bacon and eggs!" clucked a hen on a perch.
5	"Trap, trap, trap! cackle, cackle, cackle!" scolded the disturbed cockerel.
8	"To market, to market! jiggettyjig!" clucked a broody white hen roosting next to him.
7	Pigling Bland, much alarmed, determined to leave at daybreak.
9	In the meantime, he and the hens fell asleep.
9	In less than an hour they were all awakened.
9	The owner, Mr. Peter Thomas Piperson, came with a lantern and a hamper to catch six fowls to take to market in the morning.
9	He grabbed the white hen roosting next to the cock; then his eye fell upon Pigling Bland, squeezed up in a corner.
1	He made a singular remark--"Hallo, here's another!" --seized Pigling by the scruff of the neck, and dropped him into the hamper.
9	Then he dropped in five more dirty, kicking, cackling hens upon the top of Pigling Bland.
9	The hamper containing six fowls and a young pig was no light weight; it was taken down hill, unsteadily, with jerks.
9	Pigling, although nearly scratched to pieces, contrived to hide the papers and peppermints inside his clothes.
9	At last the hamper was bumped down upon a kitchen floor, the lid was opened, and Pigling was lifted out.
8	He looked up, blinking, and saw an offensively ugly elderly man, grinning from ear to ear.
9	"This one's come of himself, whatever," said Mr. Piperson, turning Pigling's pockets inside out.
9	He pushed the hamper into a corner, threw a sack over it to keep the hens quiet, put a pot on the fire, and unlaced his boots.
9	Pigling Bland drew forward a coppy stool, and sat on the edge of it, shyly warming his hands.
9	Mr. Piperson pulled off a boot and threw it against the wainscot at the further end of the kitchen.
5	There was a smothered noise--"Shut up!" said Mr. Piperson.
9	Pigling Bland warmed his hands, and eyed him.
5	Mr. Piperson pulled off the other boot and flung it after the first, there was again a curious noise-- "Be quiet, will ye?" said Mr. Piperson.
9	Pigling Bland sat on the very edge of the coppy stool.
9	Mr. Piperson fetched meal from a chest and made porridge, it seemed to Pigling that something at the further end of the kitchen was taking a suppressed interest in the cooking; but he was too hungry to be troubled by noises.
9	Mr. Piperson poured out three platefuls: for himself, for Pigling, and a third-after glaring at Pigling-- he put away with much scuffling, and locked up.
9	Pigling Bland ate his supper discreetly.
9	After supper Mr. Piperson consulted an almanac, and felt Pigling's ribs; it was too late in the season for curing bacon, and he grudged his meal.
9	Besides, the hens had seen this pig.
9	He looked at the small remains of a flitch [side of bacon], and then looked undecidedly at Pigling.
9	"You may sleep on the rug," said Mr. Peter Thomas Piperson.
9	Pigling Bland slept like a top.
9	In the morning Mr. Piperson made more porridge; the weather was warmer.
9	He looked how much meal was left in the chest, and seemed dissatisfied--"You'll likely be moving on again?" said he to Pigling Bland.
9	Before Pigling could reply, a neighbor, who was giving Mr. Piperson and the hens a lift, whistled from the gate.
5	Mr. Piperson hurried out with the hamper, enjoining Pigling to shut the door behind him and not meddle with nought; or "I'll come back and skin ye!" said Mr. Piperson.
9	It crossed Pigling's mind that if HE had asked for a lift, too, he might still have been in time for market.
7	But he distrusted Peter Thomas.
9	After finishing breakfast at his leisure, Pigling had a look round the cottage; everything was locked up.
9	He found some potato peelings in a bucket in the back kitchen.
9	Pigling ate the peel, and washed up the porridge plates in the bucket.
9	He sang while he worked--
9	"Tom with his pipe made such a noise, He called up all the girls and boys-- "And they all ran to hear him play, "Over the hills and far away!--"
9	Suddenly a little smothered voice chimed in--
9	"Over the hills and a great way off, The wind shall blow my top knot off."
1	Pigling Bland put down a plate which he was wiping, and listened.
9	After a long pause, Pigling went on tiptoe and peeped round the door into the front kitchen; there was nobody there.
9	After another pause, Pigling approached the door of the locked cupboard, and snuffed at the keyhole.
9	It was quite quiet.
9	After another long pause, Pigling pushed a peppermint under the door.
9	It was sucked in immediately.
9	In the course of the day Pigling pushed in all his remaining six peppermints.
9	When Mr. Piperson returned, he found Pigling sitting before the fire; he had brushed up the hearth and put on the pot to boil; the meal was not get-at-able.
9	Mr. Piperson was very affable; he slapped Pigling on the back, made lots of porridge and forgot to lock the meal chest.
9	He did lock the cupboard door; but without properly shutting it.
9	He went to bed early, and told Pigling upon no account to disturb him next day before twelve o'clock.
9	Pigling Bland sat by the fire, eating his supper.
9	All at once at his elbow, a little voice spoke--"My name is Pig-wig.
9	Make me more porridge, please!"
1	Pigling Bland jumped, and looked round.
8	A perfectly lovely little black Berkshire pig stood smiling beside him.
9	She had twinkly little screwed up eyes, a double chin, and a short turned up nose.
9	She pointed at Pigling's plate; he hastily gave it to her, and fled to the meal chest--"How did you come here?" asked Pigling Bland.
9	"Stolen," replied Pig-wig, with her mouth full.
9	Pigling helped himself to meal without scruple.
9	"What for?"
8	"Bacon, hams," replied Pig- wig cheerfully.
8	"I shall after supper," said Pig- wig decidedly.
8	Pigling Bland made more porridge and watched her shyly.
9	She finished a second plate, got up, and looked about her, as though she were going to start.
9	"You can't go in the dark," said Pigling Bland.
7	Pig-wig looked anxious.
9	"Do you know your way by day- light?"
9	"I know we can see this little white house from the hills across the river.
9	Which way are _you_ going, Mr. Pig?"
9	"To market--I have two pig papers.
0	I might take you to the bridge; if you have no objection," said Pigling much confused and sitting on the edge of his coppy stool.
8	Pig- wig's gratitude was such and she asked so many questions that it became embarrassing to Pigling Bland.
9	He was obliged to shut his eyes and pretend to sleep.
9	She became quiet, and there was a smell of peppermint.
9	"Only the corners," replied Pig- wig, studying the sentiments with much interest by the firelight.
7	"I wish you wouldn't; he might smell them through the ceiling," said the alarmed Pigling.
9	Pig-wig put back the sticky peppermints into her pocket; "Sing something," she demanded.
9	"I am sorry.
9	. .
0	I have tooth- ache," said Pigling much dismayed.
9	"Then I will sing," replied Pig- wig, "You will not mind if I say iddy tidditty?
9	I have forgotten some of the words."
9	Pigling Bland made no objection; he sat with his eyes half shut, and watched her.
8	She wagged her head and rocked about, clapping time and singing in a sweet little grunty voice--
9	"A funny old mother pig lived in a stye, and three little piggies had she; "(Ti idditty idditty) umph, umph, umph! and the little pigs said wee, wee!"
9	She sang successfully through three or four verses, only at every verse her head nodded a little lower, and her little twinkly eyes closed up--
9	"Those three little piggies grew peaky and lean, and lean they might very well be; "For somehow they couldn't say umph, umph, umph! and they wouldn't say wee, wee, wee!
9	"For somehow they couldn't say--
9	Pig-wig's head bobbed lower and lower, until she rolled over, a little round ball, fast asleep on the hearth-rug.
9	Pigling Bland, on tiptoe, covered her up with an antimacassar.
7	He was afraid to go to sleep himself; for the rest of the night he sat listening to the chirping of the crickets and to the snores of Mr. Piperson overhead.
9	Early in the morning, between dark and daylight, Pigling tied up his little bundle and woke up Pig- wig.
7	"But it's dark!
7	How can we find our way?"
9	"The cock has crowed; we must start before the hens come out; they might shout to Mr. Piperson."
9	"Come away Pig-wig; we can see when we get used to it.
9	Come!
7	I can hear them clucking!"
9	Pigling had never said shuh! to a hen in his life, being peaceable; also he remembered the hamper.
9	He opened the house door quietly and shut it after them.
9	There was no garden; the neighborhood of Mr. Piperson's was all scratched up by fowls.
9	They slipped away hand in hand across an untidy field to the road.
9	"Tom, Tom the piper's son, stole a pig and away he ran!
9	"But all the tune that he could play, was `Over the hills and far away!'"
9	"Come Pig-wig, we must get to the bridge before folks are stirring."
9	"Why do you want to go to market, Pigling?" inquired Pig-wig.
9	The sun rose while they were crossing the moor, a dazzle of light over the tops of the hills.
9	The sunshine crept down the slopes into the peaceful green valleys, where little white cottages nestled in gardens and orchards.
9	"That's Westmorland," said Pig- wig.
8	She dropped Pigling's hand and commenced to dance, singing-- presently.
9	"I don't want; I want to grow potatoes."
9	"Have a peppermint?" said Pig-wig.
5	Pigling Bland refused quite crossly.
9	"Does your poor toothy hurt?" inquired Pig- wig.
5	Pigling Bland grunted.
9	Pig-wig ate the peppermint herself, and followed the opposite side of the road.
