5	"Pig-wig! keep under the wall, there's a man ploughing."
9	Pig-wig crossed over, they hurried down hill towards the county boundary.
7	Suddenly Pigling stopped; he heard wheels.
9	Slowly jogging up the road below them came a tradesman's cart.
9	The reins flapped on the horse's back, the grocer was reading a newspaper.
7	"Take that peppermint out of your mouth, Pig-wig, we may have to run.
7	Don't say one word.
9	Leave it to me.
7	And in sight of the bridge!" said poor Pigling, nearly crying.
7	He began to walk frightfully lame, holding Pig-wig's arm.
9	The grocer, intent upon his newspaper, might have passed them, if his horse had not shied and snorted.
9	He pulled the cart crossways, and held down his whip.
9	"Hallo?
9	Where are you going to?"--Pigling Bland stared at him vacantly.
9	"Are you deaf?
9	Are you going to market?"
9	Pigling nodded slowly.
9	"I thought as much.
9	It was yesterday.
9	Show me your license?"
9	Pigling stared at the off hind shoe of the grocer's horse which had picked up a stone.
2	The grocer flicked his whip-- "Papers?
2	Pig license?"
9	Pigling fumbled in all his pockets, and handed up the papers.
2	The grocer read them, but still seemed dissatisfied.
1	"This here pig is a young lady; is her name Alexander?"
9	Pig-wig opened her mouth and shut it again; Pigling coughed asthmatically.
5	The grocer ran his finger down the advertisement column of his newspaper--"Lost, stolen or strayed, 10S. reward;" he looked suspiciously at Pig-wig.
9	Then he stood up in the trap, and whistled for the ploughman.
9	"You wait here while I drive on and speak to him," said the grocer, gathering up the reins.
9	He knew that pigs are slippery; but surely, such a VERY lame pig could never run!
7	"Not yet, Pig-wig, he will look back."
9	The grocer did so; he saw the two pigs stock-still in the middle of the road.
9	Then he looked over at his horse's heels; it was lame also; the stone took some time to knock out, after he got to the ploughman.
7	"Now, Pig-wig, NOW!" said Pigling Bland.
9	Never did any pigs run as these pigs ran!
9	They raced and squealed and pelted down the long white hill towards the bridge.
7	Little fat Pig- wig's petticoats fluttered, and her feet went pitter, patter, pitter, as she bounded and jumped.
9	They ran, and they ran, and they ran down the hill, and across a short cut on level green turf at the bottom, between pebble beds and rushes.
8	They came to the river, they came to the bridge--they crossed it hand in hand--then over the hills and far away she danced with Pigling Bland!
9	This is a Pussy called Miss Moppet; she thinks she has heard a mouse!
9	He is not afraid of a kitten.
1	This is Miss Moppet jumping just too late; she misses the Mouse and hits her own head.
1	She thinks it is a very hard cupboard!
9	The Mouse watches Miss Moppet from the top of the cupboard.
9	Miss Moppet ties up her head in a duster and sits before the fire.
9	The Mouse thinks she is looking very ill.
9	He comes sliding down the bellpull.
9	Miss Moppet looks worse and worse.
9	The Mouse comes a little nearer.
9	Miss Moppet holds her poor head in her paws and looks at him through a hole in the duster.
9	The Mouse comes VERY close.
1	And then all of a sudden--Miss Moppet jumps upon the Mouse!
2	And because the Mouse has teased Miss Moppet--Miss Moppet thinks she will tease the Mouse, which is not at all nice of Miss Moppet.
9	She ties him up in the duster and tosses it about like a ball.
1	But she forgot about that hole in the duster; and when she untied it-- there was no Mouse!
8	He has wriggled out and run away; and he is dancing a jig on top of the cupboard!
9	"I'll be at charges for a looking-glass; And entertain a score or two of tailors." [Richard III]
9	My Dear Freda:
9	Because you are fond of fairytales, and have been ill, I have made you a story all for yourself--a new one that nobody has read before.
9	And the queerest thing about it is--that I heard it in Gloucestershire, and that it is true--at least about the tailor, the waistcoat, and the "No more twist!" _Christmas_
9	In the time of swords and peri wigs and full-skirted coats with flowered lappets--when gentlemen wore ruffles, and gold-laced waistcoats of paduasoy and taffeta--there lived a tailor in Gloucester.
9	He sat in the window of a little shop in Westgate Street, cross-legged on a table from morning till dark.
9	All day long while the light lasted he sewed and snippetted, piecing out his satin, and pompadour, and lutestring; stuffs had strange names, and were very expensive in the days of the Tailor of Gloucester.
9	But although he sewed fine silk for his neighbours, he himself was very, very poor.
9	He cut his coats without waste; according to his embroidered cloth, they were very small ends and snippets that lay about upon the table--"Too narrow breadths for nought--except waistcoats for mice," said the tailor.
9	One bitter cold day near Christmastime the tailor began to make a coat (a coat of cherry- coloured corded silk embroidered with pansies and roses) and a cream- coloured satin waistcoat for the Mayor of Gloucester.
9	The tailor worked and worked, and he talked to himself: "No breadth at all, and cut on the cross; it is no breadth at all; tippets for mice and ribbons for mobs! for mice!" said the Tailor of Gloucester.
9	When the snow-flakes came down against the small leaded window- panes and shut out the light, the tailor had done his day's work; all the silk and satin lay cut out upon the table.
9	There were twelve pieces for the coat and four pieces for the waistcoat; and there were pocket-flaps and cuffs and buttons, all in order.
9	For the lining of the coat there was fine yellow taffeta, and for the button- holes of the waistcoat there was cherry-coloured twist.
9	And everything was ready to sew together in the morning, all measured and sufficient--except that there was wanting just one single skein of cherry-coloured twisted silk.
9	The tailor came out of his shop at dark.
9	No one lived there at nights but little brown mice, and THEY ran in and out without any keys!
9	For behind the wooden wainscots of all the old houses in Gloucester, there are little mouse staircases and secret trap-doors; and the mice run from house to house through those long, narrow passages.
9	But the tailor came out of his shop and shuffled home through the snow.
9	And although it was not a big house, the tailor was so poor he only rented the kitchen.
9	He lived alone with his cat; it was called Simpkin.
9	"Miaw?" said the cat when the tailor opened the door, "miaw?"
0	The tailor replied: "Simpkin, we shall make our fortune, but I am worn to a ravelling.
9	Take this groat (which is our last fourpence), and, Simpkin, take a china pipkin, but a penn'orth of bread, a penn'orth of milk, and a penn'orth of sausages.
9	And oh, Simpkin, with the last penny of our fourpence but me one penn'orth of cherry-coloured silk.
0	But do not lose the last penny of the fourpence, Simpkin, or I am undone and worn to a thread-paper, for I have NO MORE TWIST."
9	Then Simpkin again said "Miaw!" and took the groat and the pipkin, and went out into the dark.
0	The tailor was very tired and beginning to be ill.
9	He sat down by the hearth and talked to himself about that wonderful coat.
9	"I shall make my fortune--to be cut bias--the Mayor of Gloucester is to be married on Christmas Day in the morning, and he hath ordered a coat and an embroidered waistcoat--"
1	Then the tailor started; for suddenly, interrupting him, from the dresser at the other side of the kitchen came a number of little noises--
9	Tip tap, tip tap, tip tap tip!
1	"Now what can that be?" said the Tailor of Gloucester, jumping up from his chair.
9	The tailor crossed the kitchen, and stood quite still beside the dresser, listening, and peering through his spectacles.
1	"This is very peculiar," said the Tailor of Gloucester, and he lifted up the tea-cup which was upside down.
9	Out stepped a little live lady mouse, and made a courtesy to the tailor!
9	Then she hopped away down off the dresser, and under the wainscot.
9	The tailor sat down again by the fire, warming his poor cold hands.
9	But all at once, from the dresser, there came other little noises--
9	Tip tap, tip tap, tip tap tip!
9	Out stepped a little gentleman mouse, and made a bow to the tailor!
9	And out from under tea-cups and from under bowls and basins, stepped other and more little mice, who hopped away down off the dresser and under the wainscot.
0	The tailor sat down, close over the fire, lamenting: "One-and-twenty buttonholes of cherry-coloured silk!
9	To be finished by noon of Saturday: and this is Tuesday evening.
9	Was it right to let loose those mice, undoubtedly the property of Simpkin?
9	The little mice came out again and listened to the tailor; they took notice of the pattern of that wonderful coat.
9	They whispered to one another about the taffeta lining and about little mouse tippets.
9	And then suddenly they all ran away together down the passage behind the wainscot, squeaking and calling to one another as they ran from house to house.
9	Not one mouse was left in the tailor's kitchen when Simpkin came back.
1	He set down the pipkin of milk upon the dresser, and looked suspiciously at the tea-cups.
1	He wanted his supper of little fat mouse!
5	"Simpkin," said the tailor, "where is my TWIST?"
5	But Simpkin hid a little parcel privately in the tea-pot, and spit and growled at the tailor; and if Simpkin had been able to talk, he would have asked: "Where is my MOUSE?"
0	"Alack, I am undone!" said the Tailor of Gloucester, and went sadly to bed.
9	All that night long Simpkin hunted and searched through the kitchen, peeping into cupboards and under the wainscot, and into the tea-pot where he had hidden that twist; but still he found never a mouse!
0	The poor old tailor was very ill with a fever, tossing and turning in his four-post bed; and still in his dreams he mumbled: "No more twist! no more twist!"
9	What should become of the cherry- coloured coat?
9	Who should come to sew it, when the window was barred, and the door was fast locked?
9	Out-of-doors the market folks went trudging through the snow to buy their geese and turkeys, and to bake their Christmas pies; but there would be no dinner for Simpkin and the poor old tailor of Gloucester.
0	The tailor lay ill for three days and nights; and then it was Christmas Eve, and very late at night.
9	But it is in the old story that all the beasts can talk in the night between Christmas Eve and Christmas Day in the morning (though there are very few folk that can hear them, or know what it is that they say).
9	When the Cathedral clock struck twelve there was an answer--like an echo of the chimes--and Simpkin heard it, and came out of the tailor's door, and wandered about in the snow.
9	From all the roofs and gables and old wooden houses in Gloucester came a thousand merry voices singing the old Christmas rhymes--all the old songs that ever I heard of, and some that I don't know, like Whittington's bells.
9	Under the wooden eaves the starlings and sparrows sang of Christmas pies; the jackdaws woke up in the Cathedral tower; and although it was the middle of the night the throstles and robins sang; and air was quite full of little twittering tunes.
0	But it was all rather provoking to poor hungry Simpkin.
9	From the tailor's ship in Westgate came a glow of light; and when Simpkin crept up to peep in at the window it was full of candles.
8	There was a snippeting of scissors, and snappeting of thread; and little mouse voices sang loudly and gaily:
9	"Four-and-twenty tailors Went to catch a snail, The best man amongst them Durst not touch her tail; She put out her horns Like a little kyloe cow.
9	Run, tailors, run!
9	Or she'll have you all e'en now!"
9	Then without a pause the little mouse voices went on again:
9	"Sieve my lady's oatmeal, Grind my lady's flour, Put it in a chestnut, Let it stand an hour--"
9	"Mew!
9	Mew!" interrupted Simpkin, and he scratched at the door.
9	But the key was under the tailor's pillow; he could not get in.
8	The little mice only laughed, and tried another tune--
9	"Three little mice sat down to spin, Pussy passed by and she peeped in.
9	What are you at, my fine little men?
9	Making coats for gentlemen.
9	Shall I come in and cut off yours threads?
9	Oh, no, Miss Pussy, You'd bite off our heads!"
5	"Mew! scratch! scratch!" scuffled Simpkin on the window-sill; while the little mice inside sprang to their feet, and all began to shout all at once in little twittering voices: "No more twist!
9	No more twist!"
9	And they barred up the window-shutters and shut out Simpkin.
9	Simpkin came away from the shop and went home considering in his mind.
8	He found the poor old tailor without fever, sleeping peacefully.
9	The sun was shining on the snow when the tailor got up and dressed, and came out into the street with Simpkin running before him.
0	"Alack," said the tailor, "I have my twist; but no more strength--nor time--than will serve to make me one single buttonhole; for this is Christmas Day in the Morning!
0	The Mayor of Gloucester shall be married by noon--and where is his cherry- coloured coat?"
9	He unlocked the door of the little shop in Westgate Street, and Simpkin ran in, like a cat that expects something.
1	But there was no one there!
1	Not even one little brown mouse!
9	Everything was finished except just one single cherry-coloured buttonhole, and where that buttonhole was wanting there was pinned a scrap of paper with these words--in little teeny weeny writing--
9	NO MORE TWIST.
8	And from then began the luck of the Tailor of Gloucester; he grew quite stout, and he grew quite rich.
9	He made the most wonderful waistcoats for all the rich merchants of Gloucester, and for all the fine gentlemen of the country round.
9	Never were seen such ruffles, or such embroidered cuffs and lappets!
9	But his buttonholes were the greatest triumph of it all.
9	The stitches of those buttonholes were so neat--SO neat--I wonder how they could be stitched by an old man in spectacles, with crooked old fingers, and a tailor's thimble.
9	The stitches of those buttonholes were so small--SO small--they looked as if they had been made by little mice!
9	It is said that the effect of eating too much lettuce is "soporific."
9	I have never felt sleepy after eating lettuces; but then I am not a rabbit.
9	They certainly had a very soporific effect upon the Flopsy Bunnies!
9	When Benjamin Bunny grew up, he married his Cousin Flopsy.
8	They had a large family, and they were very improvident and cheerful.
9	I do not remember the separate names of their children; they were generally called the "Flopsy Bunnies."
9	As there was not always quite enough to eat,--Benjamin used to borrow cabbages from Flopsy's brother, Peter Rabbit, who kept a nursery garden.
9	Sometimes Peter Rabbit had no cabbages to spare.
9	When this happened, the Flopsy Bunnies went across the field to a rubbish heap, in the ditch outside Mr. McGregor's garden.
9	Mr. McGregor's rubbish heap was a mixture.
9	There were jam pots and paper bags, and mountains of chopped grass from the mowing machine (which always tasted oily), and some rotten vegetable marrows and an old boot or two.
8	One day--oh joy!--there were a quantity of overgrown lettuces, which had "shot" into flower.
8	The Flopsy Bunnies simply stuffed themselves with lettuces.
8	By degrees, one after another, they were overcome with slumber, and lay down in the mown grass.
9	Benjamin was not so much overcome as his children.
9	Before going to sleep he was sufficiently wide awake to put a paper bag over his head to keep off the flies.
8	The little Flopsy Bunnies slept delightfully in the warm sun.
9	From the lawn beyond the garden came the distant clacketty sound of the mowing machine.
9	The blue- bottles buzzed about the wall, and a little old mouse picked over the rubbish among the jam pots.
9	(I can tell you her name, she was called Thomasina Tittle- mouse, a woodmouse with a long tail.)
9	She rustled across the paper bag, and awakened Benjamin Bunny.
9	The mouse apologized profusely, and said that she knew Peter Rabbit.
9	While she and Benjamin were talking, close under the wall, they heard a heavy tread above their heads; and suddenly Mr. McGregor emptied out a sackful of lawn mowings right upon the top of the sleeping Flopsy Bunnies!
7	Benjamin shrank down under his paper bag.
7	The mouse hid in a jam pot.
8	The little rabbits smiled sweetly in their sleep under the shower of grass; they did not awake because the lettuces had been so soporific.
8	They dreamt that their mother Flopsy was tucking them up in a hay bed.
9	Mr. McGregor looked down after emptying his sack.
9	He saw some funny little brown tips of ears sticking up through the lawn mowings.
9	He stared at them for some time.
9	Presently a fly settled on one of them and it moved.
9	Mr. McGregor climbed down on to the rubbish heap--
5	"One, two, three, four! five! six leetle rabbits!" said he as he dropped them into his sack.
8	The Flopsy Bunnies dreamt that their mother was turning them over in bed.
9	They stirred a little in their sleep, but still they did not wake up.
9	Mr. McGregor tied up the sack and left it on the wall.
9	He went to put away the mowing machine.
9	While he was gone, Mrs. Flopsy Bunny (who had remained at home) came across the field.
9	Then the mouse came out of her jam pot, and Benjamin took the paper bag off his head, and they told the doleful tale.
9	But Mrs. Tittlemouse was a resourceful person.
9	She nibbled a hole in the bottom corner of the sack.
9	The little rabbits were pulled out and pinched to wake them.
9	Their parents stuffed the empty sack with three rotten vegetable marrows, an old blackingbrush and two decayed turnips.
7	Then they all hid under a bush and watched for Mr. McGregor.
9	Mr. McGregor came back and picked up the sack, and carried it off.
9	He carried it hanging down, as if it were rather heavy.
9	The Flopsy Bunnies followed at a safe distance.
9	They watched him go into his house.
9	And then they crept up to the window to listen.
9	Mr. McGregor threw down the sack on the stone floor in a way that would have been extremely painful to the Flopsy Bunnies, if they had happened to have been inside it.
8	They could hear him drag his chair on the flags, and chuckle--
8	"One, two, three, four, five, six leetle rabbits!" said Mr. McGregor.
1	"Eh?
1	What's that?
1	What have they been spoiling now?" enquired Mrs. McGregor.
1	"One, two, three, four, five, six leetle fat rabbits!" repeated Mr. McGregor, counting on his fingers --"one, two, three--"
2	"Don't you be silly: what do you mean, you silly old man?"
1	"In the sack! one, two, three, four, five, six!" replied Mr. McGregor.
9	(The youngest Flopsy Bunny got upon the windowsill.)
9	Mrs. McGregor took hold of the sack and felt it.
9	She said she could feel six, but they must be OLD rabbits, because they were so hard and all different shapes.
9	"Not fit to eat; but the skins will do fine to line my old cloak."
2	"Line your old cloak?" shouted Mr. McGregor--"I shall sell them and buy myself baccy!"
9	"Rabbit tobacco!
8	I shall skin them and cut off their heads."
9	Mrs. McGregor untied the sack and put her hand inside.
5	When she felt the vegetables she became very very angry.
5	She said that Mr. McGregor had "done it a purpose."
5	And Mr. McGregor was very angry too.
9	One of the rotten marrows came flying through the kitchen window, and hit the youngest Flopsy Bunny.
9	Then Benjamin and Flopsy thought that it was time to go home.
9	So Mr. McGregor did not get his tobacco, and Mrs. McGregor did not get her rabbit skins.
9	But next Christmas Thomasina Tittlemouse got a present of enough rabbit wool to make herself a cloak and a hood, and a handsome muff and a pair of warm mittens.
9	What a funny sight it is to see a brood of ducklings with a hen!
5	Listen to the story of Jemima Puddle-duck, who was annoyed because the farmer's wife would not let her hatch her own eggs.
5	Her sister-in-law, Mrs. Rebeccah Puddle-duck, was perfectly willing to leave the hatching to someone else-- "I have not the patience to sit on a nest for twenty-eight days; and no more have you, Jemima.
5	You would let them go cold; you know you would!"
5	"I wish to hatch my own eggs; I will hatch them all by myself," quacked Jemima Puddle-duck.
9	She tried to hide her eggs; but they were always found and carried off.
9	She determined to make a nest right away from the farm.
9	She set off on a fine spring afternoon along the cart road that leads over the hill.
9	She was wearing a shawl and a poke bonnet.
9	When she reached the top of the hill, she saw a wood in the distance.
9	She thought that it looked a safe quiet spot.
9	Jemima Puddle-duck was not much in the habit of flying.
9	She ran downhill a few yards flapping her shawl, and then she jumped off into the air.
9	She flew beautifully when she had got a good start.
9	She skimmed along over the treetops until she saw an open place in the middle of the wood, where the trees and brushwood had been cleared.
9	Jemima alighted rather heavily and began to waddle about in search of a convenient dry nesting place.
8	She rather fancied a tree stump amongst some tall foxgloves.
1	But--seated upon the stump, she was startled to find an elegantly dressed gentleman reading a newspaper.
9	He had black prick ears and sandy colored whiskers.
7	"Quack?" said Jemima Puddle- duck, with her head and her bonnet on the one side--"Quack?"
9	The gentleman raised his eyes above his newspaper and looked curiously at Jemima--
9	"Madam, have you lost your way?" said he.
9	He had a long bushy tail which he was sitting upon, as the stump was somewhat damp.
9	Jemima thought him mighty civil and handsome.
9	She explained that she had not lost her way, but that she was trying to find a convenient dry nesting place.
9	"Ah! is that so?
8	Indeed!" said the gentleman with sandy whiskers, looking curiously at Jemima.
9	He folded up the newspaper and put it in his coattail pocket.
5	Jemima complained of the superfluous hen.
8	"Indeed!
8	How interesting!
9	I wish I could meet with that fowl.
9	I would teach it to mind its own business!
9	"But as to a nest--there is no difficulty: I have a sackful of feathers in my woodshed.
9	No, my dear madam, you will be in nobody's way.
9	You may sit there as long as you like," said the bushy long-tailed gentleman.
9	He led the way to a very retired, dismal-looking house amongst the foxgloves.
9	It was built of faggots and turf, and there were two broken pails, one on top of another, by way of a chimney.
9	"This is my summer residence; you would not find my earth--my winter house--so convenient," said the hospitable gentleman.
9	There was a tumbledown shed at the back of the house, made of old soap boxes.
9	The gentleman opened the door and showed Jemima in.
9	The shed was almost quite full of feathers--it was almost suffocating; but it was comfortable and very soft.
1	Jemima Puddle-duck was rather surprised to find such a vast quantity of feathers.
1	But it was very comfortable; and she made a nest without any trouble at all.
9	When she came out, the sandy- whiskered gentleman was sitting on a log reading the newspaper--at least he had it spread out, but he was looking over the top of it.
0	He was so polite that he seemed almost sorry to let Jemima go home for the night.
9	He promised to take great care of her nest until she came back again the next day.
8	He said he loved eggs and ducklings; he should be proud to see a fine nestful in his woodshed.
9	Jemima Puddle-duck came every afternoon; she laid nine eggs in the nest.
9	They were greeny white and very large.
8	The foxy gentleman admired them immensely.
8	He used to turn them over and count them when Jemima was not there.
9	At last Jemima told him that she intended to begin to sit next day--"and I will bring a bag of corn with me, so that I need never leave my nest until the eggs are hatched.
9	They might catch cold," said the conscientious Jemima.
9	"Madam, I beg you not to trouble yourself with a bag; I will provide oats.
9	But before you commence your tedious sitting, I intend to give you a treat.
8	Let us have a dinner party all to ourselves!
9	"May I ask you to bring up some herbs from the farm garden to make a savory omelet?
9	Sage and thyme, and mint and two onions, and some parsley.
9	I will provide lard for the stuff--lard for the omelet," said the hospitable gentleman with sandy whiskers.
9	Jemima Puddle-duck was a simpleton: not even the mention of sage and onions made her suspicious.
9	She went round the farm garden, nibbling off snippets of all the different sorts of herbs that are used for stuffing roast duck.
9	And she waddled into the kitchen and got two onions out of a basket.
9	The collie dog Kep met her coming out, "What are you doing with those onions?
9	Where do you go every afternoon by yourself, Jemima Puddle-duck?"
8	The collie listened, with his wise head on one side; he grinned when she described the polite gentleman with sandy whiskers.
9	He asked several questions about the wood and about the exact position of the house and shed.
9	Then he went out, and trotted down the village.
9	He went to look for two foxhound puppies who were out at walk with the butcher.
9	Jemima Puddle-duck went up the cart road for the last time, on a sunny afternoon.
9	She was rather burdened with bunches of herbs and two onions in a bag.
9	She flew over the wood, and alighted opposite the house of the bushy long-tailed gentleman.
7	He was sitting on a log; he sniffed the air and kept glancing uneasily round the wood.
9	"Come into the house as soon as you have looked at your eggs.
9	Give me the herbs for the omelet.
5	Be sharp!"
7	He was rather abrupt.
9	Jemima Puddle-duck had never heard him speak like that.
1	She felt surprised and uncomfortable.
9	While she was inside she heard pattering feet round the back of the shed.
9	Someone with a black nose sniffed at the bottom of the door, and them locked it.
7	Jemima became much alarmed.
9	A moment afterward there were most awful noises--barking, baying, growls and howls, squealing and groans.
9	And nothing more was ever seen of that foxy-whiskered gentleman.

0	Jemima Puddle-duck was escorted home in tears on account of those eggs.
9	She laid some more in June, and she was permitted to keep them herself: but only four of them hatched.
9	Jemima Puddle-duck said that it was because of her nerves; but she had always been a bad sitter.
9	Once upon a time there was a little girl called Lucie, who lived at a farm called Little-town.
9	She was a good little girl--only she was always losing her pocket-handkerchiefs!
0	One day little Lucie came into the farm-yard crying--oh, she did cry so!
0	"I've lost my pocket-handkin!
0	Three handkins and a pinny!
0	Have YOU seen them, Tabby Kitten?"
9	The Kitten went on washing her white paws; so Lucie asked a speckled hen--
0	"Sally Henny-penny, have YOU found three pocket-handkins?"
9	But the speckled hen ran into a barn, clucking--
9	"I go barefoot, barefoot, barefoot!"
9	And then Lucie asked Cock Robin sitting on a twig.
9	Cock Robin looked sideways at Lucie with his bright black eye, and he flew over a stile and away.
9	Lucie climbed upon the stile and looked up at the hill behind Little- town--a hill that goes up--up--into the clouds as though it had no top!
1	And a great way up the hillside she thought she saw some white things spread upon the grass.
9	Lucie scrambled up the hill as fast as her short legs would carry her; she ran along a steep path-way--up and up--until Little-town was right away down below--she could have dropped a pebble down the chimney!
9	Presently she came to a spring, bubbling out from the hillside.
9	Some one had stood a tin can upon a stone to catch the water--but the water was already running over, for the can was no bigger than an egg- cup!
9	And where the sand upon the path was wet--there were footmarks of a VERY small person.
9	Lucie ran on, and on.
9	The path ended under a big rock.
1	The grass was short and green, and there were clothes-props cut from bracken stems, with lines of plaited rushes, and a heap of tiny clothes pins--but no pocket-handkerchiefs!
9	But there was something else--a door! straight into the hill; and inside it some one was singing--
9	"Lily-white and clean, oh!
9	With little frills between, oh!
9	Smooth and hot-red rusty spot Never here be seen, oh!"
9	Lucie knocked-once-twice, and interrupted the song.
7	A little frightened voice called out "Who's that?"
9	Lucie opened the door: and what do you think there was inside the hill?--a nice clean kitchen with a flagged floor and wooden beams-- just like any other farm kitchen.
9	Only the ceiling was so low that Lucie's head nearly touched it; and the pots and pans were small, and so was everything there.
7	There was a nice hot singey smell; and at the table, with an iron in her hand, stood a very stout short person staring anxiously at Lucie.
9	Her print gown was tucked up, and she was wearing a large apron over her striped petticoat.
1	Her little black nose went sniffle, sniffle, snuffle, and her eyes went twinkle, twinkle; and underneath her cap-where Lucie had yellow curls-that little person had PRICKLES!
9	"Who are you?" said Lucie.
9	"Have you seen my pocket-handkins?"
8	The little person made a bob- curtsey--"Oh yes, if you please'm; my name is Mrs. Tiggy-winkle; oh yes if you please'm, I'm an excellent clear- starcher!"
9	And she took something out of the clothesbasket, and spread it on the ironing-blanket.
9	"What's that thing?" said Lucie- "that's not my pocket-handkin?"
9	"Oh no, if you please'm; that's a little scarlet waist-coat belonging to Cock Robin!"
9	And she ironed it and folded it, and put it on one side.
9	Then she took something else off a clothes-horse--"That isn't my pinny?" said Lucie.
9	"Oh no, if you please'm; that's a damask table-cloth belonging to Jenny Wren; look how it's stained with currant wine!
2	It's very bad to wash!" said Mrs. Tiggy-winkle.
9	Mrs. Tiggy-winkle's nose went sniffle sniffle snuffle, and her eyes went twinkle twinkle; and she fetched another hot iron from the fire.
9	Mrs. Tiggy-winkle ironed it, and goffered it, and shook out the frills.
8	"Oh that IS lovely!" said Lucie.
9	"And what are those long yellow things with fingers like gloves?"
9	"Oh that's a pair of stockings belonging to Sally Henny-penny--look how she's worn the heels out with scratching in the yard!
9	She'll very soon go barefoot!" said Mrs. Tiggy-winkle.
9	"Why, there's another hankersniff-- but it isn't mine; it's red?"
2	"Oh no, if you please'm; that one belongs to old Mrs. Rabbit; and it DID so smell of onions!
2	I've had to wash it separately, I can't get out that smell."
1	"There's another one of mine," said Lucie.
9	"What are those funny little white things?"
9	"That's a pair of mittens belonging to Tabby Kitten; I only have to iron them; she washes them herself."
1	"There's my last pocket-handkin!" said Lucie.
9	"And what are you dipping into the basin of starch?"
9	"They're little dicky shirt-fronts belonging to Tom Titmouse--most terrible particular!" said Mrs. Tiggy- winkle.
9	"Now I've finished my ironing; I'm going to air some clothes."
9	"What are these dear soft fluffy things?" said Lucie.
9	"Oh those are woolly coats belonging to the little lambs at Skelghyl."
9	"Will their jackets take off?" asked Lucie.
9	"Oh yes, if you please'm; look at the sheep-mark on the shoulder.
9	And here's one marked for Gatesgarth, and three that come from Little-town.
9	They're ALWAYS marked at washing!" said Mrs. Tiggy-winkle.
9	And she hung up all sorts and sizes of clothes--small brown coats of mice; and one velvety black moleskin waist-coat; and a red tail-coat with no tail belonging to Squirrel Nutkin; and a very much shrunk blue jacket belonging to Peter Rabbit; and a petticoat, not marked, that had gone lost in the washing--and at last the basket was empty!
9	Then Mrs. Tiggy-winkle made tea--a cup for herself and a cup for Lucie.
9	They sat before the fire on a bench and looked sideways at one another.
2	Mrs. Tiggy-winkle's hand, holding the tea-cup, was very very brown, and very very wrinkly with the soap-suds; and all through her gown and her cap, there were HAIRPINS sticking wrong end out; so that Lucie didn't like to sit too near her.
9	When they had finished tea, they tied up the clothes in bundles; and Lucie's pocket-handkerchiefs were folded up inside her clean pinny, and fastened with a silver safety-pin.
9	And then they made up the fire with turf, and came out and locked the door, and hid the key under the door-sill.
9	Then away down the hill trotted Lucie and Mrs. Tiggy-winkle with the bundles of clothes!
9	All the way down the path little animals came out of the fern to meet them; the very first that they met were Peter Rabbit and Benjamin Bunny!
8	And she gave them their nice clean clothes; and all the little animals and birds were so very much obliged to dear Mrs. Tiggy-winkle.
9	So that at the bottom of the hill when they came to the stile, there was nothing left to carry except Lucie's one little bundle.

1	THERE lived once upon a time a wicked prince whose heart and mind were set upon conquering all the countries of the world, and on frightening the people; he devastated their countries with fire and sword, and his soldiers trod down the crops in the fields and destroyed the peasants' huts by fire, so that the flames licked the green leaves off the branches, and the fruit hung dried up on the singed black trees.
8	The prince was of opinion that all this was right, and that it was only the natural course which things ought to take.
7	His power increased day by day, his name was feared by all, and fortune favoured his deeds.
0	But they did not know what endless misery he had brought upon other countries, nor did they hear the sighs and lamentations which rose up from the debris of the destroyed cities.
8	The prince often looked with delight upon his gold and his magnificent edifices, and thought, like the crowd: "What a mighty prince!
8	No power on earth must equal mine, far less exceed it."

8	All these tones of joy and song in the bottle were like the working of a young poet's brain, who often knows not the meaning of the tones which are sounding within him.
8	She was young and pretty; her brown eyes laughed, and a smile lingered round her mouth as sweet as that in her eyes.
0	There had been a great deal of talk on this subject while the basket was being packed, and during this conversation the eyes and the mouth of the furrier's daughter did not wear a very joyful expression.
8	It remained there a long time; but when at last it was brought forth it appeared as if something pleasant had happened, for every one was laughing; the furrier's daughter laughed too, but she said very little, and her cheeks were like two roses.
1	What a strange sensation it was to have the cork drawn for the first time!
8	"Long life to the betrothed," cried the papa, and every glass was emptied to the dregs, while the young sailor kissed his beautiful bride.
8	"Happiness and blessing to you both," said the old people-father and mother, and the young man filled the glasses again.
8	"Safe return, and a wedding this day next year," he cried; and when the glasses were empty he took the bottle, raised it on high, and said, "Thou hast been present here on the happiest day of my life; thou shalt never be used by others!"
2	"I gave them wine, and they gave me muddy water," he had said to himself, "but I suppose it was all well meant."
8	He could no longer see the betrothed couple, nor the cheerful old people; but for a long time he could hear them rejoicing and singing.
8	Those were happy days, and the bottle would sing when rubbed with a cork, and it was called a great lark," "Peter Jensen's lark."
0	At the last moment, when the ship was sinking, the young mate wrote on a piece of paper, "We are going down: God's will be done."
1	"What trouble they have taken with that bottle over yonder!" said one, and very likely it is broken after all."
1	But the bottle was not broken, and, better still, it understood every word that was said: this language it had heard at the furnaces and at the wine merchant's; in the forest and on the ship,- it was the only good old language it could understand.
8	It had returned home, and the language was as a welcome greeting.
8	For very joy, it felt ready to jump out of people's hands, and scarcely noticed that its cork had been drawn, and its contents emptied out, till it found itself carried to a cellar, to be left there and forgotten.
8	"There's no place like home, even if it's a cellar."
8	It never occurred to him to think that he might lie there for years, he felt so comfortable.
8	The stars twinkled; and the new moon, in the form of a crescent, was surrounded by the shadowy disc of the whole moon, and looked like a gray globe with a golden rim: it was a beautiful sight for those who had good eyes.
8	Everything here appeared lovely to our bottle, for it was again in the green wood, amid joy and feasting; again it heard music and song, and the noise and murmur of a crowd, especially in that part of the garden where the lamps blazed, and the paper lanterns displayed their brilliant colors.
8	It stood in a distant walk certainly, but a place pleasant for contemplation; and it carried a light; and was at once useful and ornamental.
8	It seemed to the bottle as if he were living that time over again.
8	Not only the guests but other people were walking in the garden, who were allowed to witness the splendor and the festivities.
8	She was thinking, like the bottle, of the green wood, and of a young betrothed pair, who were closely connected with herself; she was thinking of that hour, the happiest of her life, in which she had taken part, when she had herself been one of that betrothed pair; such hours are never to be forgotten, let a maiden be as old as she may.
8	The rabbit was quite excited because he knew that he was to be taken up, and let down again in a parachute.
8	Then the ropes which held it were cut through, and the aerial ship rose in the air with the aeronaut and the basket containing the bottle and the rabbit, while the music sounded and all the people shouted "Hurrah."
8	"This is a wonderful journey up into the air," thought the bottle; "it is a new way of sailing, and here, at least, there is no fear of striking against anything."
1	Then it began to descend much more rapidly than the rabbit had done, made somersaults in the air, and felt itself quite young and unfettered, although it was half full of wine.

8	Before the sprig you gave me faded, I took a spray, and planted it in the earth; and now, as you see, it has become a large tree, and a bunch of the blossoms shall at last appear at a wedding festival, in the bouquet of your daughter."

1	And indeed nobody was home, for the old man was dead.

8	The sparrows assembled in dozens upon the wild vines, and chattered all together as loud as they could, but not about the old house; none of them could remember it, for many years had passed by, so many indeed, that the little boy was now a man, and a really good man too, and his parents were very proud of him.

8	She has a hymn-book with large silver clasps, in which she often reads; and in the book, between the leaves, lies a rose, quite flat and dry; it is not so pretty as the roses which are standing in the glass, and yet she smiles at it most pleasantly, and tears even come into her eyes.
8	Why, when grandmother's tears fall upon the rose, and she is looking at it, the rose revives, and fills the room with its fragrance; the walls vanish as in a mist, and all around her is the glorious green wood, where in summer the sunlight streams through thick foliage; and grandmother, why she is young again, a charming maiden, fresh as a rose, with round, rosy cheeks, fair, bright ringlets, and a figure pretty and graceful; but the eyes, those mild, saintly eyes, are the same,- they have been left to grandmother.

8	The little boy said not a word; he was half pleased and half afraid.
8	But the grandest appeared when the door of a side room opened; the little boy could remember what beautiful things he had seen there, but to-night everything shone in its brightest colors.
8	As they passed from hall to hall, beauty everywhere showed itself; and as the Metal Pig went step by step from one picture to the other, the little boy could see it all plainly.
8	One glory eclipsed another; yet there was one picture that fixed itself on the little boy's memory, more especially because of the happy children it represented, for these the little boy had seen in daylight.
8	The Florentine, Angiolo Bronzino, painted this picture; most beautiful is the expression on the face of the two children, who appear to have full confidence that they shall reach heaven at last.
8	They are embracing each other, and one little one stretches out his hand towards another who stands below him, and points to himself, as if he were saying, "I am going to heaven."

7	We dried her clothes as well as we were able, and remained on the water till they were dry; for we did not wish it to be known what a fright we had had, nor the danger which our little adopted sister had incurred, in whose life Aphtanides had now a part.
8	How peaceful and silent it was as we walked on through the thick, wild thyme, still fragrant, though the sun had scorched the leaves.
7	My mother lighted a fire, and roasted some roots she had brought with her, and I and my little sister slept among the bushes, without fear of the ugly smidraki, from whose throat issues fire, or of the wolf and the jackal; for my mother sat by us, and I considered her presence sufficient protection.

8	The whole of nature was one large holy church, in which the trees and hovering clouds formed the pillars, the flowers and grass the woven velvet carpet, and heaven itself was the great cupola; up there the flame colour vanished as soon as the sun disappeared, but millions of stars were lighted; diamond lamps were shining, and the king's son stretched his arms out towards heaven, towards the sea, and towards the wood.

8	The little people who now play on that spot know nothing of the old tale, else would they fancy they heard a child crying deep below the earth, and the dewdrops on each blade of grass would be to them tears of woe.

8	"Ding-dong! ding-dong!" sounded the Bell, when the tower still stood there; and one evening, while the sun was setting, and the Bell was swinging away bravely, it broke loose and came flying down through the air, the brilliant metal shining in the ruddy beam.

0	But the Bell got neither rest nor sleep.
8	Down in the Au-mann's haunt it sounds and rings, so that the tones sometimes pierce upward through the waters; and many people maintain that its strains forebode the death of some one; but that is not true, for the Bell is only talking with the Au-mann, who is now no longer alone.

8	"The church bell hangs high, and looks far around, and sees the birds around it, and understands their language.
8	The wind roars in upon it through windows and loopholes; and the wind knows everything, for he gets it from the air, which encircles all things, and the church bell understands his tongue, and rings it out into the world, 'Ding-dong! ding-dong!'
